basic.title: Complete: Compression Definition
basic.content:
Complete the definition for Compression Definition:
"Automatic reduction of dynamic range - making loud _______ quieter and/or quiet parts louder."
basic.explanation:
Compression Definition

Automatic reduction of dynamic range - making loud parts quieter and/or quiet parts louder.

What is Dynamic Range:

  • Difference between loudest and quietest parts of audio
  • Wide dynamic range: Large difference (classical music, acoustic recordings)
  • Narrow dynamic range: Small difference (modern pop, radio-ready)

What Compression Does:

  • Reduces peaks (makes loud parts quieter)
  • Can raise average level (makeup gain)
  • Creates more consistent level
  • Controls dynamics automatically

Why Use Compression:

  • Control peaks: Prevent clipping
  • Increase perceived loudness: Raise average level
  • Consistency: Even out performance dynamics
  • Tone shaping: Add punch, sustain, character
  • Glue: Make elements sit together in mix
  • Creative effect: Pumping, breathing, vintage character

How It Works: 1. Signal exceeds threshold 2. Compressor reduces gain (based on ratio) 3. Reduction happens over attack time 4. Signal returns to normal over release time 5. Makeup gain added if desired

Types of Dynamic Processing:

  • Downward Compression: Reduces level above threshold (most common)
  • Upward Compression: Raises level below threshold (less common)
  • Limiting: Extreme compression preventing signal exceeding ceiling
  • Expansion: Increases dynamic range
  • Gating: Silences signal below threshold

---

basic.title: Threshold (in dB)

answers.text: How gradually compression transitions from no compression to full compression.
Difference between loudest and quietest parts of audio.
Level at which compression begins to activate.

basic.explanation:
Threshold (in dB)

Level at which compression begins to activate.

Definition:

  • Signal level where compressor starts working
  • Above threshold: compression applied
  • Below threshold: signal passes unaffected
  • Measured in: dBFS (digital) or dBu (analog)

Setting Threshold:

  • Higher threshold (-10dB): Less compression, only loudest peaks affected
  • Medium threshold (-20dB): Moderate compression, balanced
  • Lower threshold (-40dB): More compression, affects more of signal
  • Very low threshold (-60dB): Almost entire signal compressed

Visual Indicators:

  • Gain reduction meter shows compression amount
  • More gain reduction = lower threshold or higher ratio
  • Typical: 3-10dB gain reduction for subtle compression
  • Heavy: 10-20dB+ gain reduction for obvious effect

Threshold by Application:

  • Vocals: -15dB to -25dB (moderate, controls peaks)
  • Drums: -10dB to -20dB (varies by drum)
  • Bass: -20dB to -30dB (lower, more compression)
  • Mix Bus: -5dB to -10dB (high, gentle compression)

Relationship with Ratio:

  • Lower threshold + lower ratio: Gentle overall compression
  • Higher threshold + higher ratio: Aggressive peak control
  • Interactive: Both affect amount of compression

Auto Threshold:

  • Some compressors: automatically set threshold
  • Adapts to: input signal level
  • Less common: manual control preferred for precision

---

basic.title: Complete: Ratio (2:1, 4:1, 10:1, ∞:1)
basic.content:
Complete the definition for Ratio (2:1, 4:1, 10:1, ∞:1):
"Amount of compression applied to signal _______ threshold."
basic.explanation:
Ratio (2:1, 4:1, 10:1, ∞:1)

Amount of compression applied to signal exceeding threshold.

Definition:

  • Input:Output ratio
  • Example: 4:1 = 4dB input increase creates 1dB output increase
  • Higher ratio: more compression (more aggressive)
  • Lower ratio: less compression (more transparent)

Common Ratios:

2:1 (Gentle):

  • Very subtle compression
  • Transparent, natural
  • Use: Overall mix control, mastering, gentle leveling
  • Effect: Barely noticeable, smooth
  • Application: Mix bus, mastering, classical music

4:1 (Moderate):

  • Standard compression
  • Musical, versatile
  • Use: Vocals, bass, instruments
  • Effect: Noticeable but natural
  • Application: Most music production, general purpose

6:1 to 8:1 (Heavy):

  • Strong compression
  • Obvious effect
  • Use: Aggressive vocal control, pumping effects
  • Effect: Clear compression, sustained notes
  • Application: Parallel compression, special effects

10:1 to 20:1 (Limiting):

  • Very aggressive compression
  • Approaching limiting
  • Use: Peak control, protection
  • Effect: Very sustained, controlled
  • Application: Peak limiting, drum transient control

∞:1 (Brick-Wall Limiting):

  • True limiting
  • Signal cannot exceed threshold
  • Use: Final limiter, absolute peak control
  • Effect: Hard ceiling, no peaks above threshold
  • Application: Mastering limiter, live sound protection

Calculation Example:

  • Threshold: -20dB
  • Ratio: 4:1
  • Input peak: -10dB (10dB above threshold)
  • Compression: 10dB ÷ 4 = 2.5dB allowed through
  • Output: -20dB + 2.5dB = -17.5dB
  • Gain reduction: 7.5dB

Ratio by Genre:

  • Classical/Jazz: 2:1 to 3:1 (preserve dynamics)
  • Rock/Pop: 4:1 to 6:1 (controlled, consistent)
  • Electronic/Hip-Hop: 6:1 to 10:1 (aggressive, loud)
  • Mastering: 1.5:1 to 3:1 (very gentle)

Variable Ratio:

  • Some compressors: ratio changes with input level
  • Example: Gentle at low levels, aggressive at peaks
  • More musical: responds to dynamics naturally

---

basic.title: Complete: Release Time (10ms - 5 seconds)
basic.content:
Complete the definition for Release Time (10ms - 5 seconds):
"Time compressor _______ to return to unity gain after signal drops below threshold."
basic.explanation:
Release Time (10ms - 5 seconds)

Time compressor takes to return to unity gain after signal drops below threshold.

Definition:

  • Time for gain reduction to return to 0dB
  • Fast release: quick recovery (10-100ms)
  • Slow release: slow recovery (500ms-5s)
  • Controls: how compression "breathes"

Release Time Effects:

Fast Release (10-100ms):

  • Quickly returns to normal
  • Follows dynamics closely
  • Sounds: Pumping, breathing, obvious
  • Use: Creative pumping effects, sidechaining
  • Risk: Distortion on low frequencies, obvious pumping

Medium Release (100-500ms):

  • Balanced recovery
  • Musical, transparent
  • Sounds: Natural, smooth
  • Use: General compression, most mixing
  • Sweet spot: Works for most material

Slow Release (500ms-5s):

  • Slow return to normal
  • Smooth, gentle
  • Sounds: Sustained, even, glue
  • Use: Bus compression, gentle leveling, glue
  • Application: Mix bus, mastering, pads

Auto Release:

  • Compressor adapts release time automatically
  • Responds to: program material
  • Fast release: for fast transients
  • Slow release: for sustained material
  • Examples: 1176 (all buttons), many modern compressors

Release by Application:

  • Drums: 50-200ms (quick recovery between hits)
  • Bass: 100-400ms (follows note pattern)
  • Vocals: 100-500ms (smooth, natural)
  • Mix Bus: 300ms-1s (slow, smooth, glue)
  • Parallel Compression: 10-50ms (fast, aggressive)

Release and Pumping:

  • Too fast: audible pumping/breathing
  • Too slow: compression doesn't recover, sounds over-compressed
  • Match tempo: Musical release times sync with tempo
  • Example: 120 BPM = 500ms per beat (try 250ms, 500ms, 1000ms)

Rule of Thumb:

  • Set release: so gain reduction returns to ~0dB before next transient
  • Too fast: distortion, pumping
  • Too slow: doesn't recover in time
  • Just right: smooth, musical

---

basic.title: Gain Reduction (Metering)

answers.text: Visual display showing amount of compression being applied.
Software-based or DSP-based compression with mathematical precision.
Using multiple compressors in series (one after another) with gentle settings.
Two different ways to measure audio level.

basic.explanation:
Gain Reduction (Metering)

Visual display showing amount of compression being applied.

What It Shows:

  • How much gain is being reduced
  • Measured in: negative dB (-3dB, -6dB, -10dB)
  • Real-time display
  • Essential for: setting compression amount

Reading Gain Reduction Meter:

  • 0dB: No compression (signal below threshold or bypassed)
  • -3dB: Light compression
  • -6dB: Moderate compression
  • -10dB: Heavy compression
  • -15dB+: Very aggressive compression

Typical Gain Reduction by Application:

  • Subtle compression: 1-3dB (transparent, gentle)
  • Standard compression: 3-8dB (musical, controlled)
  • Heavy compression: 8-15dB (obvious, aggressive)
  • Limiting: 10-20dB+ (peak control, loudness)

Watching Gain Reduction:

  • Constant: May be over-compressed (release too slow)
  • Pumping: Normal for dynamic material
  • Only peaks: Good (threshold set correctly)
  • Never triggering: Threshold too high or ratio too low

Gain Reduction vs Ratio:

  • Same gain reduction: can be achieved different ways
  • Low threshold + low ratio: Gentle overall compression
  • High threshold + high ratio: Aggressive peak compression
  • Sound different: even with same meter reading

Professional Practice:

  • Set threshold/ratio: watching gain reduction meter
  • Aim for: 3-6dB on most material (starting point)
  • More compression: if desired effect
  • Less compression: if sounding squashed

---

basic.title: Input vs Output (A/B Comparison)

answers.text: Time compressor takes to return to unity gain after signal drops below threshold.
Comparing compressed signal to original at matched levels.
Peaks between samples occurring during D/A conversion.

basic.explanation:
Input vs Output (A/B Comparison)

Comparing compressed signal to original at matched levels.

Why Important:

  • Louder: always sounds "better"
  • Compression: often makes signal louder
  • Must compare: at same level for honest assessment
  • Only way: to judge if compression improving sound

How to Compare: 1. Set compression as desired 2. Add makeup gain to match bypassed level 3. A/B bypass on/off rapidly 4. Listen for: tonal changes, control, character (not loudness)

What to Listen For:

  • Tighter control: Good compression
  • Loss of punch: Too much compression or too fast attack
  • Pumping/breathing: Inappropriate attack/release times
  • Distortion: Too much gain reduction or fast attack/release
  • Character: Tonal coloration (can be good or bad)

Professional Practice:

  • Always match levels before deciding
  • If unsure: bypass and compare
  • Compression should: improve sound, not just make louder

---

[Content continues in Part 2 with Compressor Types]

basic.title: Complete: Attack Time (0.1ms - 100ms)
basic.content:
Complete the definition for Attack Time (0.1ms - 100ms):
"Time compressor takes to _______ after signal exceeds threshold."
basic.explanation:
Attack Time (0.1ms - 100ms)

Time compressor takes to react after signal exceeds threshold.

Definition:

  • Time to reach full compression amount
  • Fast attack: quick response (0.1-10ms)
  • Slow attack: delayed response (20-100ms)
  • Controls: how much transient passes through

Attack Time Effects:

Fast Attack (0.1-5ms):

  • Catches transients immediately
  • Reduces peak level effectively
  • Sounds: controlled, tight, less dynamic
  • Use: Aggressive compression, peak control
  • Application: Limiters, bass compression, drum control
  • Trade-off: Can sound squashed, loss of punch

Medium Attack (5-20ms):

  • Lets some transient through
  • Balances control and impact
  • Sounds: natural, punchy, controlled
  • Use: General purpose, most mixing
  • Application: Vocals, guitars, general instruments
  • Sweet spot: Musical and effective

Slow Attack (20-100ms+):

  • Lets transients pass unaffected
  • Compresses sustain/body only
  • Sounds: punchy, dynamic, natural
  • Use: Preserve impact, enhance punch
  • Application: Drums (enhance attack), bass (preserve pick/slap)
  • Adds: apparent punchiness

Attack by Instrument:

  • Drums: 5-30ms (preserve attack, control sustain)
  • Bass: 10-40ms (let pick/slap through, control body)
  • Vocals: 5-20ms (fast enough to control, not too aggressive)
  • Guitar: 10-30ms (preserve pick attack)
  • Mix Bus: 20-50ms (gentle, musical)

Attack and Transients:

  • Faster attack: less transient through (less punch)
  • Slower attack: more transient through (more punch)
  • Paradox: Slow attack can make drums sound louder/punchier
  • Transient passes: perceived as louder even though sustain compressed

Auto Attack:

  • Some compressors: automatically adjust attack
  • Program-dependent: responds to material
  • Examples: LA-2A (optical), certain digital compressors

---

basic.title: Complete: Makeup Gain
basic.content:
Complete the definition for Makeup Gain:
"Adds gain after compression to _______ output level."
basic.explanation:
Makeup Gain

Adds gain after compression to restore output level.

Purpose:

  • Compression reduces level (gain reduction)
  • Makeup gain restores perceived loudness
  • Brings signal back to desired level
  • Allows: A/B comparison at matched levels

Auto Makeup Gain:

  • Automatically compensates for gain reduction
  • Output level: matches input level
  • Convenient: no manual adjustment
  • Found in: many modern compressors
  • Can be: slightly imprecise

Manual Makeup Gain:

  • User sets output level manually
  • More precise control
  • Better for: critical listening, subtle compression
  • Professional preference: manual control

How Much Makeup Gain:

  • General rule: Add back 50-75% of gain reduction
  • Example: 10dB gain reduction → add 5-7dB makeup gain
  • Why not 100%: Compressed signal has higher average level
  • Goal: Match perceived loudness, not peak level

Listening Levels:

  • Critical: Compare bypassed vs compressed at same perceived level
  • Louder: always sounds "better" (Fletcher-Munson)
  • Match levels: for honest comparison
  • Use: makeup gain to match loudness

Applications:

  • Always use: makeup gain for fair comparison
  • Parallel compression: less makeup gain (blending with dry)
  • Heavy compression: more makeup gain needed
  • Gentle compression: minimal makeup gain

---

basic.title: Complete: Input and Output Gain
basic.content:
Complete the definition for Input and Output Gain:
"Controls signal level _______ into and coming out of compressor."
basic.explanation:
Input and Output Gain

Controls signal level going into and coming out of compressor.

Input Gain:

  • Boosts signal before compression
  • More input gain: More gain reduction (pushes into threshold)
  • Used in: vintage compressors (control compression amount)
  • Modern digital: Typically not used (set threshold instead)

Output Gain:

  • Same as: Makeup gain
  • Boosts signal after compression
  • Restores: apparent loudness
  • Balances: input and output levels

Gain Staging:

  • Input: Set for appropriate level into compressor
  • Threshold: Set for desired compression amount
  • Output: Match original level (or desired level)
  • Goal: No level change when bypassing (fair comparison)

---

basic.title: Knee (Hard vs Soft)

answers.text: Controls signal level going into and coming out of compressor.
How gradually compression transitions from no compression to full compression.
Increases dynamics by raising loud parts.
Time compressor takes to react after signal exceeds threshold.

basic.explanation:
Knee (Hard vs Soft)

How gradually compression transitions from no compression to full compression.

Hard Knee:

  • Abrupt transition at threshold
  • Compression starts immediately when signal crosses threshold
  • Full ratio applied instantly
  • Characteristics: Precise, controlled, obvious
  • Sound: Can be harsh, aggressive
  • Use: Peak limiting, aggressive compression, precise control
  • Visual: Sharp angle at threshold on curve

Soft Knee:

  • Gradual transition around threshold
  • Compression starts below threshold gradually increasing
  • Reaches full ratio above threshold
  • Characteristics: Smooth, musical, natural
  • Sound: Transparent, gentle, musical
  • Use: Subtle compression, musical control, mix bus
  • Visual: Rounded curve at threshold

Knee Range:

  • 0dB (Hard Knee): No transition zone
  • 6dB: Small transition zone (3dB below to 3dB above threshold)
  • 12dB: Medium transition zone (6dB below to 6dB above)
  • 24dB+: Wide transition zone (very gradual)

How Soft Knee Works:

  • 12dB soft knee, -20dB threshold:
  • Compression starts: -26dB (6dB below threshold)
  • Gradually increases
  • Reaches full ratio: -14dB (6dB above threshold)

Applications:

  • Hard Knee: Limiters, aggressive compression, electronic music, precise peak control
  • Soft Knee: Mix bus, mastering, gentle compression, natural control, vocals (transparent)

Tonal Character:

  • Hard knee: More obvious, can add character
  • Soft knee: More transparent, less noticeable
  • Some compressors: switchable, some fixed

---

intermediate.title: Identify: Threshold (in dB)
intermediate.content: Which term best describes: "Level at which compression begins to activate."?
intermediate.explanation:
Threshold (in dB)

Level at which compression begins to activate.

Definition:

  • Signal level where compressor starts working
  • Above threshold: compression applied
  • Below threshold: signal passes unaffected
  • Measured in: dBFS (digital) or dBu (analog)

Setting Threshold:

  • Higher threshold (-10dB): Less compression, only loudest peaks affected
  • Medium threshold (-20dB): Moderate compression, balanced
  • Lower threshold (-40dB): More compression, affects more of signal
  • Very low threshold (-60dB): Almost entire signal compressed

Visual Indicators:

  • Gain reduction meter shows compression amount
  • More gain reduction = lower threshold or higher ratio
  • Typical: 3-10dB gain reduction for subtle compression
  • Heavy: 10-20dB+ gain reduction for obvious effect

Threshold by Application:

  • Vocals: -15dB to -25dB (moderate, controls peaks)
  • Drums: -10dB to -20dB (varies by drum)
  • Bass: -20dB to -30dB (lower, more compression)
  • Mix Bus: -5dB to -10dB (high, gentle compression)

Relationship with Ratio:

  • Lower threshold + lower ratio: Gentle overall compression
  • Higher threshold + higher ratio: Aggressive peak control
  • Interactive: Both affect amount of compression

Auto Threshold:

  • Some compressors: automatically set threshold
  • Adapts to: input signal level
  • Less common: manual control preferred for precision

---

intermediate.title: Identify: Ratio (2:1, 4:1, 10:1, ∞:1)
intermediate.content: Which term best describes: "Amount of compression applied to signal exceeding threshold."?
intermediate.explanation:
Ratio (2:1, 4:1, 10:1, ∞:1)

Amount of compression applied to signal exceeding threshold.

Definition:

  • Input:Output ratio
  • Example: 4:1 = 4dB input increase creates 1dB output increase
  • Higher ratio: more compression (more aggressive)
  • Lower ratio: less compression (more transparent)

Common Ratios:

2:1 (Gentle):

  • Very subtle compression
  • Transparent, natural
  • Use: Overall mix control, mastering, gentle leveling
  • Effect: Barely noticeable, smooth
  • Application: Mix bus, mastering, classical music

4:1 (Moderate):

  • Standard compression
  • Musical, versatile
  • Use: Vocals, bass, instruments
  • Effect: Noticeable but natural
  • Application: Most music production, general purpose

6:1 to 8:1 (Heavy):

  • Strong compression
  • Obvious effect
  • Use: Aggressive vocal control, pumping effects
  • Effect: Clear compression, sustained notes
  • Application: Parallel compression, special effects

10:1 to 20:1 (Limiting):

  • Very aggressive compression
  • Approaching limiting
  • Use: Peak control, protection
  • Effect: Very sustained, controlled
  • Application: Peak limiting, drum transient control

∞:1 (Brick-Wall Limiting):

  • True limiting
  • Signal cannot exceed threshold
  • Use: Final limiter, absolute peak control
  • Effect: Hard ceiling, no peaks above threshold
  • Application: Mastering limiter, live sound protection

Calculation Example:

  • Threshold: -20dB
  • Ratio: 4:1
  • Input peak: -10dB (10dB above threshold)
  • Compression: 10dB ÷ 4 = 2.5dB allowed through
  • Output: -20dB + 2.5dB = -17.5dB
  • Gain reduction: 7.5dB

Ratio by Genre:

  • Classical/Jazz: 2:1 to 3:1 (preserve dynamics)
  • Rock/Pop: 4:1 to 6:1 (controlled, consistent)
  • Electronic/Hip-Hop: 6:1 to 10:1 (aggressive, loud)
  • Mastering: 1.5:1 to 3:1 (very gentle)

Variable Ratio:

  • Some compressors: ratio changes with input level
  • Example: Gentle at low levels, aggressive at peaks
  • More musical: responds to dynamics naturally

---

intermediate.title: Identify: Makeup Gain
intermediate.content: Which term best describes: "Adds gain after compression to restore output level."?
intermediate.explanation:
Makeup Gain

Adds gain after compression to restore output level.

Purpose:

  • Compression reduces level (gain reduction)
  • Makeup gain restores perceived loudness
  • Brings signal back to desired level
  • Allows: A/B comparison at matched levels

Auto Makeup Gain:

  • Automatically compensates for gain reduction
  • Output level: matches input level
  • Convenient: no manual adjustment
  • Found in: many modern compressors
  • Can be: slightly imprecise

Manual Makeup Gain:

  • User sets output level manually
  • More precise control
  • Better for: critical listening, subtle compression
  • Professional preference: manual control

How Much Makeup Gain:

  • General rule: Add back 50-75% of gain reduction
  • Example: 10dB gain reduction → add 5-7dB makeup gain
  • Why not 100%: Compressed signal has higher average level
  • Goal: Match perceived loudness, not peak level

Listening Levels:

  • Critical: Compare bypassed vs compressed at same perceived level
  • Louder: always sounds "better" (Fletcher-Munson)
  • Match levels: for honest comparison
  • Use: makeup gain to match loudness

Applications:

  • Always use: makeup gain for fair comparison
  • Parallel compression: less makeup gain (blending with dry)
  • Heavy compression: more makeup gain needed
  • Gentle compression: minimal makeup gain

---

intermediate.title: Identify: Release Time (10ms - 5 seconds)
intermediate.content: Which term best describes: "Time compressor takes to return to unity gain after signal drops below threshold."?
intermediate.explanation:
Release Time (10ms - 5 seconds)

Time compressor takes to return to unity gain after signal drops below threshold.

Definition:

  • Time for gain reduction to return to 0dB
  • Fast release: quick recovery (10-100ms)
  • Slow release: slow recovery (500ms-5s)
  • Controls: how compression "breathes"

Release Time Effects:

Fast Release (10-100ms):

  • Quickly returns to normal
  • Follows dynamics closely
  • Sounds: Pumping, breathing, obvious
  • Use: Creative pumping effects, sidechaining
  • Risk: Distortion on low frequencies, obvious pumping

Medium Release (100-500ms):

  • Balanced recovery
  • Musical, transparent
  • Sounds: Natural, smooth
  • Use: General compression, most mixing
  • Sweet spot: Works for most material

Slow Release (500ms-5s):

  • Slow return to normal
  • Smooth, gentle
  • Sounds: Sustained, even, glue
  • Use: Bus compression, gentle leveling, glue
  • Application: Mix bus, mastering, pads

Auto Release:

  • Compressor adapts release time automatically
  • Responds to: program material
  • Fast release: for fast transients
  • Slow release: for sustained material
  • Examples: 1176 (all buttons), many modern compressors

Release by Application:

  • Drums: 50-200ms (quick recovery between hits)
  • Bass: 100-400ms (follows note pattern)
  • Vocals: 100-500ms (smooth, natural)
  • Mix Bus: 300ms-1s (slow, smooth, glue)
  • Parallel Compression: 10-50ms (fast, aggressive)

Release and Pumping:

  • Too fast: audible pumping/breathing
  • Too slow: compression doesn't recover, sounds over-compressed
  • Match tempo: Musical release times sync with tempo
  • Example: 120 BPM = 500ms per beat (try 250ms, 500ms, 1000ms)

Rule of Thumb:

  • Set release: so gain reduction returns to ~0dB before next transient
  • Too fast: distortion, pumping
  • Too slow: doesn't recover in time
  • Just right: smooth, musical

---

intermediate.title: Identify: Knee (Hard vs Soft)
intermediate.content: Which term best describes: "How gradually compression transitions from no compression to full compression."?
intermediate.explanation:
Knee (Hard vs Soft)

How gradually compression transitions from no compression to full compression.

Hard Knee:

  • Abrupt transition at threshold
  • Compression starts immediately when signal crosses threshold
  • Full ratio applied instantly
  • Characteristics: Precise, controlled, obvious
  • Sound: Can be harsh, aggressive
  • Use: Peak limiting, aggressive compression, precise control
  • Visual: Sharp angle at threshold on curve

Soft Knee:

  • Gradual transition around threshold
  • Compression starts below threshold gradually increasing
  • Reaches full ratio above threshold
  • Characteristics: Smooth, musical, natural
  • Sound: Transparent, gentle, musical
  • Use: Subtle compression, musical control, mix bus
  • Visual: Rounded curve at threshold

Knee Range:

  • 0dB (Hard Knee): No transition zone
  • 6dB: Small transition zone (3dB below to 3dB above threshold)
  • 12dB: Medium transition zone (6dB below to 6dB above)
  • 24dB+: Wide transition zone (very gradual)

How Soft Knee Works:

  • 12dB soft knee, -20dB threshold:
  • Compression starts: -26dB (6dB below threshold)
  • Gradually increases
  • Reaches full ratio: -14dB (6dB above threshold)

Applications:

  • Hard Knee: Limiters, aggressive compression, electronic music, precise peak control
  • Soft Knee: Mix bus, mastering, gentle compression, natural control, vocals (transparent)

Tonal Character:

  • Hard knee: More obvious, can add character
  • Soft knee: More transparent, less noticeable
  • Some compressors: switchable, some fixed

---

intermediate.title: Identify: Attack Time (0.1ms - 100ms)
intermediate.content: Which term best describes: "Time compressor takes to react after signal exceeds threshold."?
intermediate.explanation:
Attack Time (0.1ms - 100ms)

Time compressor takes to react after signal exceeds threshold.

Definition:

  • Time to reach full compression amount
  • Fast attack: quick response (0.1-10ms)
  • Slow attack: delayed response (20-100ms)
  • Controls: how much transient passes through

Attack Time Effects:

Fast Attack (0.1-5ms):

  • Catches transients immediately
  • Reduces peak level effectively
  • Sounds: controlled, tight, less dynamic
  • Use: Aggressive compression, peak control
  • Application: Limiters, bass compression, drum control
  • Trade-off: Can sound squashed, loss of punch

Medium Attack (5-20ms):

  • Lets some transient through
  • Balances control and impact
  • Sounds: natural, punchy, controlled
  • Use: General purpose, most mixing
  • Application: Vocals, guitars, general instruments
  • Sweet spot: Musical and effective

Slow Attack (20-100ms+):

  • Lets transients pass unaffected
  • Compresses sustain/body only
  • Sounds: punchy, dynamic, natural
  • Use: Preserve impact, enhance punch
  • Application: Drums (enhance attack), bass (preserve pick/slap)
  • Adds: apparent punchiness

Attack by Instrument:

  • Drums: 5-30ms (preserve attack, control sustain)
  • Bass: 10-40ms (let pick/slap through, control body)
  • Vocals: 5-20ms (fast enough to control, not too aggressive)
  • Guitar: 10-30ms (preserve pick attack)
  • Mix Bus: 20-50ms (gentle, musical)

Attack and Transients:

  • Faster attack: less transient through (less punch)
  • Slower attack: more transient through (more punch)
  • Paradox: Slow attack can make drums sound louder/punchier
  • Transient passes: perceived as louder even though sustain compressed

Auto Attack:

  • Some compressors: automatically adjust attack
  • Program-dependent: responds to material
  • Examples: LA-2A (optical), certain digital compressors

---

intermediate.title: Identify: Input and Output Gain
intermediate.content: Which term best describes: "Controls signal level going into and coming out of compressor."?
intermediate.explanation:
Input and Output Gain

Controls signal level going into and coming out of compressor.

Input Gain:

  • Boosts signal before compression
  • More input gain: More gain reduction (pushes into threshold)
  • Used in: vintage compressors (control compression amount)
  • Modern digital: Typically not used (set threshold instead)

Output Gain:

  • Same as: Makeup gain
  • Boosts signal after compression
  • Restores: apparent loudness
  • Balances: input and output levels

Gain Staging:

  • Input: Set for appropriate level into compressor
  • Threshold: Set for desired compression amount
  • Output: Match original level (or desired level)
  • Goal: No level change when bypassing (fair comparison)

---

intermediate.title: Identify: Gain Reduction (Metering)
intermediate.content: Which term best describes: "Visual display showing amount of compression being applied."?
intermediate.explanation:
Gain Reduction (Metering)

Visual display showing amount of compression being applied.

What It Shows:

  • How much gain is being reduced
  • Measured in: negative dB (-3dB, -6dB, -10dB)
  • Real-time display
  • Essential for: setting compression amount

Reading Gain Reduction Meter:

  • 0dB: No compression (signal below threshold or bypassed)
  • -3dB: Light compression
  • -6dB: Moderate compression
  • -10dB: Heavy compression
  • -15dB+: Very aggressive compression

Typical Gain Reduction by Application:

  • Subtle compression: 1-3dB (transparent, gentle)
  • Standard compression: 3-8dB (musical, controlled)
  • Heavy compression: 8-15dB (obvious, aggressive)
  • Limiting: 10-20dB+ (peak control, loudness)

Watching Gain Reduction:

  • Constant: May be over-compressed (release too slow)
  • Pumping: Normal for dynamic material
  • Only peaks: Good (threshold set correctly)
  • Never triggering: Threshold too high or ratio too low

Gain Reduction vs Ratio:

  • Same gain reduction: can be achieved different ways
  • Low threshold + low ratio: Gentle overall compression
  • High threshold + high ratio: Aggressive peak compression
  • Sound different: even with same meter reading

Professional Practice:

  • Set threshold/ratio: watching gain reduction meter
  • Aim for: 3-6dB on most material (starting point)
  • More compression: if desired effect
  • Less compression: if sounding squashed

---

intermediate.title: Identify: Compression Definition
intermediate.content: Which term best describes: "Automatic reduction of dynamic range - making loud parts quieter and/or quiet parts louder."?
intermediate.explanation:
Compression Definition

Automatic reduction of dynamic range - making loud parts quieter and/or quiet parts louder.

What is Dynamic Range:

  • Difference between loudest and quietest parts of audio
  • Wide dynamic range: Large difference (classical music, acoustic recordings)
  • Narrow dynamic range: Small difference (modern pop, radio-ready)

What Compression Does:

  • Reduces peaks (makes loud parts quieter)
  • Can raise average level (makeup gain)
  • Creates more consistent level
  • Controls dynamics automatically

Why Use Compression:

  • Control peaks: Prevent clipping
  • Increase perceived loudness: Raise average level
  • Consistency: Even out performance dynamics
  • Tone shaping: Add punch, sustain, character
  • Glue: Make elements sit together in mix
  • Creative effect: Pumping, breathing, vintage character

How It Works: 1. Signal exceeds threshold 2. Compressor reduces gain (based on ratio) 3. Reduction happens over attack time 4. Signal returns to normal over release time 5. Makeup gain added if desired

Types of Dynamic Processing:

  • Downward Compression: Reduces level above threshold (most common)
  • Upward Compression: Raises level below threshold (less common)
  • Limiting: Extreme compression preventing signal exceeding ceiling
  • Expansion: Increases dynamic range
  • Gating: Silences signal below threshold

---

intermediate.title: Identify: Input vs Output (A/B Comparison)
intermediate.content: Which term best describes: "Comparing compressed signal to original at matched levels."?
intermediate.explanation:
Input vs Output (A/B Comparison)

Comparing compressed signal to original at matched levels.

Why Important:

  • Louder: always sounds "better"
  • Compression: often makes signal louder
  • Must compare: at same level for honest assessment
  • Only way: to judge if compression improving sound

How to Compare: 1. Set compression as desired 2. Add makeup gain to match bypassed level 3. A/B bypass on/off rapidly 4. Listen for: tonal changes, control, character (not loudness)

What to Listen For:

  • Tighter control: Good compression
  • Loss of punch: Too much compression or too fast attack
  • Pumping/breathing: Inappropriate attack/release times
  • Distortion: Too much gain reduction or fast attack/release
  • Character: Tonal coloration (can be good or bad)

Professional Practice:

  • Always match levels before deciding
  • If unsure: bypass and compare
  • Compression should: improve sound, not just make louder

---

Applications:

  • Hard Knee: Limiters, aggressive compression, electronic music, precise peak control
  • Soft Knee: Mix bus, mastering, gentle compression, natural control, vocals (transparent)

Tonal Character:

  • Hard knee: More obvious, can add character
  • Soft knee: More transparent, less noticeable
  • Some compressors: switchable, some fixed

---

advanced.title: Concept: Compression Definition
advanced.content: True or False: Compression Definition is defined as: Automatic reduction of dynamic range - making loud parts quieter and/or quiet parts louder.
advanced.explanation:
Compression Definition

Automatic reduction of dynamic range - making loud parts quieter and/or quiet parts louder.

What is Dynamic Range:

  • Difference between loudest and quietest parts of audio
  • Wide dynamic range: Large difference (classical music, acoustic recordings)
  • Narrow dynamic range: Small difference (modern pop, radio-ready)

What Compression Does:

  • Reduces peaks (makes loud parts quieter)
  • Can raise average level (makeup gain)
  • Creates more consistent level
  • Controls dynamics automatically

Why Use Compression:

  • Control peaks: Prevent clipping
  • Increase perceived loudness: Raise average level
  • Consistency: Even out performance dynamics
  • Tone shaping: Add punch, sustain, character
  • Glue: Make elements sit together in mix
  • Creative effect: Pumping, breathing, vintage character

How It Works: 1. Signal exceeds threshold 2. Compressor reduces gain (based on ratio) 3. Reduction happens over attack time 4. Signal returns to normal over release time 5. Makeup gain added if desired

Types of Dynamic Processing:

  • Downward Compression: Reduces level above threshold (most common)
  • Upward Compression: Raises level below threshold (less common)
  • Limiting: Extreme compression preventing signal exceeding ceiling
  • Expansion: Increases dynamic range
  • Gating: Silences signal below threshold

---

advanced.title: Concept: Gain Reduction (Metering)
advanced.content: True or False: Gain Reduction (Metering) is defined as: Visual display showing amount of compression being applied.
advanced.explanation:
Gain Reduction (Metering)

Visual display showing amount of compression being applied.

What It Shows:

  • How much gain is being reduced
  • Measured in: negative dB (-3dB, -6dB, -10dB)
  • Real-time display
  • Essential for: setting compression amount

Reading Gain Reduction Meter:

  • 0dB: No compression (signal below threshold or bypassed)
  • -3dB: Light compression
  • -6dB: Moderate compression
  • -10dB: Heavy compression
  • -15dB+: Very aggressive compression

Typical Gain Reduction by Application:

  • Subtle compression: 1-3dB (transparent, gentle)
  • Standard compression: 3-8dB (musical, controlled)
  • Heavy compression: 8-15dB (obvious, aggressive)
  • Limiting: 10-20dB+ (peak control, loudness)

Watching Gain Reduction:

  • Constant: May be over-compressed (release too slow)
  • Pumping: Normal for dynamic material
  • Only peaks: Good (threshold set correctly)
  • Never triggering: Threshold too high or ratio too low

Gain Reduction vs Ratio:

  • Same gain reduction: can be achieved different ways
  • Low threshold + low ratio: Gentle overall compression
  • High threshold + high ratio: Aggressive peak compression
  • Sound different: even with same meter reading

Professional Practice:

  • Set threshold/ratio: watching gain reduction meter
  • Aim for: 3-6dB on most material (starting point)
  • More compression: if desired effect
  • Less compression: if sounding squashed

---

advanced.title: Concept: Input vs Output (A/B Comparison)
advanced.content: True or False: Input vs Output (A/B Comparison) is defined as: Using external signal to trigger compression.
advanced.explanation:
Input vs Output (A/B Comparison)

Comparing compressed signal to original at matched levels.

Why Important:

  • Louder: always sounds "better"
  • Compression: often makes signal louder
  • Must compare: at same level for honest assessment
  • Only way: to judge if compression improving sound

How to Compare: 1. Set compression as desired 2. Add makeup gain to match bypassed level 3. A/B bypass on/off rapidly 4. Listen for: tonal changes, control, character (not loudness)

What to Listen For:

  • Tighter control: Good compression
  • Loss of punch: Too much compression or too fast attack
  • Pumping/breathing: Inappropriate attack/release times
  • Distortion: Too much gain reduction or fast attack/release
  • Character: Tonal coloration (can be good or bad)

Professional Practice:

  • Always match levels before deciding
  • If unsure: bypass and compare
  • Compression should: improve sound, not just make louder

---

[Content continues in Part 2 with Compressor Types]

basic.title: Optical Compressor

answers.text: Smooth, natural compression using light-dependent resistor (photo-cell).
Reducing level when external signal present (opposite of gating).
Time compressor takes to return to unity gain after signal drops below threshold.

basic.explanation:
Optical Compressor

Smooth, natural compression using light-dependent resistor (photo-cell).

Technology:

  • Light source (LED or electroluminescent panel)
  • Photoresistor (light-dependent resistor)
  • Signal controls light intensity
  • Light controls resistance
  • Resistance controls gain
  • Physical lag creates character

Characteristics:

  • Slow, smooth attack: Physical lag (no instant response)
  • Program-dependent release: Faster for fast material, slower for sustained
  • Natural, musical: Most transparent, least obvious
  • Impossible to over-compress: Smooth even at extreme settings
  • Warm character: Gentle harmonic enhancement
  • Slow response: Not good for fast transients (use FET or VCA)

Famous Optical Compressors:

  • Teletronix LA-2A: Legendary since 1965, T4 optical cell, tube makeup amp, vocal standard #1 choice worldwide, $3,000-4,500 (reissue), $8,000+ (vintage)
  • Teletronix LA-3A: Solid-state version, slightly faster, $2,500-3,500
  • Tube-Tech CL 1B: Modern optical, tube, $2,800
  • Manley ELOP: Variable-mu/optical hybrid, expensive, $3,300

LA-2A Characteristics:

  • Fixed ratio: Approximately 3:1 (program-dependent)
  • Two knobs: Peak Reduction (threshold), Gain (makeup)
  • Simple to use: Almost impossible to make sound bad
  • Smooth compression: Very musical, transparent
  • T4 optical cell: Unique slow release characteristic
  • Tube makeup gain: Warmth and character

Program-Dependent Release:

  • Fast material (drums): faster release (avoids pumping)
  • Sustained material (vocals): slower release (smooth)
  • Automatic - no control needed
  • One reason LA-2A sounds so good

Sound Character:

  • Smooth, warm, gentle
  • Transparent even with heavy compression
  • Natural-sounding
  • "Invisible" compression
  • Musical, never harsh

Best For:

  • Vocals (absolute standard, every genre)
  • Bass (smooth, warm, controlled)
  • Acoustic instruments (transparent)
  • Mix bus (gentle glue, invisible)
  • Anything needing smooth, natural compression

Why LA-2A is #1 Vocal Compressor:

  • Simple (two knobs - hard to get wrong)
  • Smooth (never harsh or aggressive)
  • Musical (program-dependent release)
  • Character (tube and optical warmth)
  • Forgiving (hard to over-compress)

Professional Use: LA-2A on lead vocals is studio standard worldwide. Found in every professional studio. Smooth bass compression. Gentle mix bus glue.

---

basic.title: Serial Compression (Stacked/Multiple)

answers.text: Using multiple compressors in series (one after another) with gentle settings.
Opposite of compressor - increases dynamic range.
Amount of compression applied to signal exceeding threshold.

basic.explanation:
Serial Compression (Stacked/Multiple)

Using multiple compressors in series (one after another) with gentle settings.

Concept:

  • Compressor 1: First stage (3-4dB reduction)
  • Compressor 2: Second stage (3-4dB reduction)
  • Total: 6-8dB reduction, but smoother than single compressor

Why Multiple Compressors:

  • Each compressor works less hard
  • More transparent (smaller gain reduction per stage)
  • Different characters combine
  • More natural than heavy single compression

Typical Chain:

  • Stage 1: Fast compressor (FET) - control peaks (2-3dB)
  • Stage 2: Smooth compressor (optical) - even out body (3-4dB)
  • Stage 3: Final glue (VCA on mix bus) - final control (1-2dB)

Common Combinations:

  • 1176 → LA-2A: FET peaks, optical smoothing (classic vocal chain)
  • Fast VCA → Slow VCA: Peaks then body
  • API 2500 → SSL Bus: Two VCAs, different characters
  • Plugin chains: Multiple plugins, different characters

Applications:

  • Vocals: Multiple gentle stages (more natural than single heavy)
  • Mix bus: Gentle compression at multiple points
  • Mastering: Typically 2-3 stages of gentle compression

Professional Practice: Each stage 3-4dB maximum. Total 6-12dB across chain. More transparent than 12dB from single compressor.

---

basic.title: Parallel Compression (New York Compression)

answers.text: Blending heavily compressed signal with dry uncompressed signal.
Automatic volume reduction when other source present.
Difference between loudest and quietest parts of audio.

basic.explanation:
Parallel Compression (New York Compression)

Blending heavily compressed signal with dry uncompressed signal.

Concept: 1. Original signal sent to two paths 2. Path 1: Dry, uncompressed (natural dynamics) 3. Path 2: Heavily compressed (10-20dB reduction, aggressive) 4. Both paths mixed together 5. Result: punch of dry + power of compressed

Setup:

  • Aux send method: Send to aux track with compressor, blend
  • Duplicate track: Duplicate, compress copy, blend
  • Parallel knob: Some compressors have built-in dry/wet blend

Compression Settings for Parallel:

  • Ratio: 10:1 or higher (very aggressive)
  • Threshold: Low (lots of compression, 15-20dB reduction)
  • Attack: Fast to medium (1-20ms)
  • Release: Medium to fast (50-200ms)
  • Makeup Gain: Bring up to match dry signal

Blend Ratio:

  • Dry: 70-90%
  • Compressed: 10-30%
  • Adjust to taste (more compressed = more power, less dynamics)

Why It Works:

  • Preserves transients (dry signal)
  • Adds thickness and sustain (compressed signal)
  • Best of both worlds (dynamic + powerful)
  • Natural + controlled

Applications:

  • Drums: Classic use (especially famous on drum room mics)
  • Vocals: Powerful but natural
  • Bass: Thick but dynamic
  • Mix bus: Subtle glue without over-compression

Famous Example: Chris Lord-Alge (engineer) popularized in 1980s-90s. Called "New York Compression" due to NYC studio origins.

---

basic.title: Complete: Upward Compression
basic.content:
Complete the definition for Upward Compression:
"Raising quieter parts instead of lowering louder parts (opposite of normal _______"
basic.explanation:
Upward Compression

Raising quieter parts instead of lowering louder parts (opposite of normal compression).

Concept:

  • Normal compression: lowers peaks above threshold
  • Upward compression: raises quiet parts below threshold
  • Reduces dynamic range from bottom up (not top down)
  • Final result similar, but process opposite

When to Use:

  • Detailed, quiet passages need boosting
  • Want to preserve peak dynamics
  • Bring up room sound, ambience
  • Enhance sustain and decay tails

Difference from Normal Compression:

  • Normal: Makes loud quieter (subtractive)
  • Upward: Makes quiet louder (additive)
  • Can be less audible (preserves peaks)

Applications:

  • Enhancing quiet details
  • Bringing up room ambience
  • Less common (most compressors don't offer)
  • More common in mastering

Available In:

  • Some mastering processors
  • Specialized plugins (DMG Limitless, Pro-C 2)
  • Less common than downward

---

[Content continues in Part 3 with Limiting, Gates, Expanders, and De-essers]

basic.title: Complete: Digital Compressor
basic.content:
Complete the definition for Digital Compressor:
"Software-based or _______ compression with mathematical precision."
basic.explanation:
Digital Compressor

Software-based or DSP-based compression with mathematical precision.

Technology:

  • Purely mathematical algorithms
  • No analog circuitry
  • Can model any compressor type
  • Perfect recall
  • Consistent (no component drift)

Characteristics:

  • Clean: No analog noise or distortion (unless modeled)
  • Precise: Perfect ratio and threshold
  • Flexible: Any attack/release time
  • Visual feedback: Detailed metering and graphs
  • Consistent: Sounds same every time
  • Affordable: Software plugins vs hardware

Types of Digital Compressors:

Transparent/Clean:

  • FabFilter Pro-C 2 (extremely versatile, visual feedback)
  • DMG Limitless (modern, precise)
  • Stock DAW compressors (Logic, Pro Tools)

Analog Modeling:

  • Universal Audio 1176 plugin (models FET)
  • Waves CLA-2A (models LA-2A optical)
  • Slate VBC (models vintage compressors)
  • Plugin Alliance SSL, API, Neve (model VCA)

Advantages:

  • Unlimited instances (hardware = one unit)
  • Perfect recall (save/load settings instantly)
  • Visual feedback (see exactly what's happening)
  • Affordable (free to $200 vs $2,000-60,000 hardware)
  • No maintenance (no tubes to replace)

Disadvantages:

  • Can sound sterile (without analog modeling)
  • No tactile interface (mouse vs knobs)
  • CPU usage (many instances = high CPU)
  • Lacks analog "mistakes" (happy accidents)

Best Modern Plugins:

  • FabFilter Pro-C 2: Versatile, visual, $179
  • Waves SSL G-Master: VCA model, $179
  • UAD 1176 Collection: FET model, $299
  • UAD Teletronix LA-2A: Optical model, $299
  • Slate VBC: Multiple vintage models, $149

Professional Use: Digital compression standard in modern production. Mix of stock plugins and analog models. Use clean digital for utility, analog models for character.

---

#

3. Advanced Compression Techniques

basic.title: Complete: VCA Compressor (Voltage Controlled Amplifier)
basic.content:
Complete the definition for VCA Compressor (Voltage Controlled Amplifier):
"Modern, _______ precise compression using solid-state VCA chip."
basic.explanation:
VCA Compressor (Voltage Controlled Amplifier)

Modern, clean, precise compression using solid-state VCA chip.

Technology:

  • Voltage controlled amplifier circuit
  • VCA chip (dbx, THAT, SSM) controls gain
  • Fast, accurate response
  • Clean, transparent (or colored by design)

Characteristics:

  • Fast attack/release: Can be extremely fast (<0.1ms attack)
  • Precise control: Accurate ratio and threshold
  • Versatile: Works on any source material
  • Clean or colored: Design-dependent (SSL colored, dbx clean)
  • Punchy: Excellent transient control

Famous VCA Compressors:

  • SSL Bus Compressor (G-Series): Industry standard mix bus, punchy, glue, 4:1 ratio with auto-release, $3,000-8,000
  • dbx 160: Clean, precise, broadcast/live, $500-800
  • API 2500: Stereo bus, three compression "knees," punchy, $2,500-3,200
  • Neve 33609: British character, smooth, mix bus, $6,000-8,000

Sound Character:

  • SSL: Punchy, aggressive, forward (rock, pop)
  • dbx: Clean, transparent, utility
  • API: Punchy, thick, musical (all genres)
  • Neve: Smooth, warm, gentle (classic)

Best For:

  • Mix bus compression (SSL, API)
  • Drums (punchy, fast)
  • Bass (tight, controlled)
  • Versatile all-around use

Attack/Release:

  • Can be very fast (instant peak control)
  • Or slow (gentle compression)
  • Full range of speeds available

Modern Standard: Most common type in modern production. Found in every studio.

---

basic.title: FET Compressor (Field Effect Transistor)

answers.text: Comparing compressed signal to original at matched levels.
Time gate stays open after signal falls below threshold.
Specialized compressor reducing harsh sibilance (s, t, sh sounds).
Fast, aggressive compression using FET transistor circuit.

basic.explanation:
FET Compressor (Field Effect Transistor)

Fast, aggressive compression using FET transistor circuit.

Technology:

  • Field Effect Transistor controls gain
  • Ultra-fast response (microseconds)
  • All-button-in mode (1176)
  • Harmonic distortion adds character

Characteristics:

  • Ultra-fast attack: Fastest compressor type (20-800µs on 1176)
  • Aggressive character: Adds punch and excitement
  • Harmonic color: Warm distortion, especially when pushed
  • Limited controls: Often simpler interface
  • Best on transients: Drums, percussion, plucked instruments

Famous FET Compressors:

  • Universal Audio 1176: Industry legend since 1967, ultra-fast, all-buttons-in mode, vocals/drums/bass standard, $2,500-4,000 (reissue), $5,000+ (vintage Rev A/E)
  • Empirical Labs Distressor: Modern FET, extremely versatile, "Brit Mode," $2,000-2,500
  • Purple Audio MC77: 1176 clone, high quality, $1,800

1176 Characteristics:

  • Fastest attack: 20µs to 800µs (microseconds!)
  • Four ratios: 4:1, 8:1, 12:1, 20:1
  • All-buttons-in: Press all ratio buttons = aggressive, distinctive sound (not true ratio)
  • Inverse controls: Clockwise = less compression (vintage quirk)
  • Character: Punchy, aggressive, adds excitement

All-Buttons-In Mode (1176):

  • Cult following effect
  • Not designed feature (discovered by users)
  • Approximately 12:1 ratio with unique distortion
  • Very aggressive, exciting sound
  • Famous on drums (room mics), bass, electric guitar

Sound Character:

  • Aggressive, forward, in-your-face
  • Adds punch and presence
  • Harmonic excitement
  • "Larger than life" quality

Best For:

  • Vocals (aggressive, present, cutting through mix)
  • Drums (snare, room mics - punchy and aggressive)
  • Bass (tight, forward, controlled)
  • Electric guitar (add punch)
  • Anything needing attitude

Professional Use: Go-to for vocals in rock/pop. 1176 most recorded-through compressor in history. Classic on snare drum, bass, rock vocals.

---

basic.title: Variable-Mu Compressor (Tube)

answers.text: Raising quieter parts instead of lowering louder parts (opposite of normal compression).
Dynamic processing in final mastering stage.
Using external signal to trigger compression.
Vintage tube compressor using tube gain reduction.

basic.explanation:
Variable-Mu Compressor (Tube)

Vintage tube compressor using tube gain reduction.

Technology:

  • Vacuum tubes (valves)
  • Tube bias controlled by input signal
  • Changes tube's amplification factor (mu)
  • All-tube signal path
  • Transformer-coupled

Characteristics:

  • Smooth, gentle compression: Very musical
  • Slow attack: Natural, transparent
  • Harmonic coloration: Tube warmth and saturation
  • Expensive: Tubes, transformers, complex circuit
  • Heavy: Large iron transformers
  • High maintenance: Tubes need replacement

Famous Variable-Mu Compressors:

  • Fairchild 670: Holy grail of compressors, 1959 design, 65 pounds, 20 tubes, $30,000-60,000+ (original vintage), $10,000-15,000 (modern reissues)
  • Manley Variable Mu: Modern classic, stereo, $4,200
  • Pendulum OCL-2: High-end modern, $6,000

Fairchild 670 Characteristics:

  • Stereo: Two channels, can be linked
  • Variable threshold: 6 threshold positions
  • Time constants: 6 settings (attack/release combinations)
  • Transformers: Input and output transformers (character)
  • Weight: 65 pounds! (massive iron)
  • Sound: Ultimate smooth, glue, warmth

Sound Character:

  • Smoothest compression available
  • Thick, warm, 3D quality
  • "Glue" effect on mix
  • Harmonic richness
  • Vintage, classic sound

Best For:

  • Mix bus (ultimate glue)
  • Mastering (smooth, transparent)
  • Vocals (warm, smooth)
  • Anything needing vintage character
  • High-end productions

Why So Expensive:

  • Complex tube circuit (20 tubes in 670)
  • Large transformers (expensive, heavy)
  • Vintage units rare (high demand)
  • Modern reissues still expensive (parts, labor)

Professional Use: Mix bus compression on high-end albums. Mastering. When budget allows and need ultimate smoothness. Beatles, Led Zeppelin used Fairchild 670.

---

intermediate.title: Identify: Parallel Compression (New York Compression)
intermediate.content: Which term best describes: "Blending heavily compressed signal with dry uncompressed signal."?
intermediate.explanation:
Parallel Compression (New York Compression)

Blending heavily compressed signal with dry uncompressed signal.

Concept: 1. Original signal sent to two paths 2. Path 1: Dry, uncompressed (natural dynamics) 3. Path 2: Heavily compressed (10-20dB reduction, aggressive) 4. Both paths mixed together 5. Result: punch of dry + power of compressed

Setup:

  • Aux send method: Send to aux track with compressor, blend
  • Duplicate track: Duplicate, compress copy, blend
  • Parallel knob: Some compressors have built-in dry/wet blend

Compression Settings for Parallel:

  • Ratio: 10:1 or higher (very aggressive)
  • Threshold: Low (lots of compression, 15-20dB reduction)
  • Attack: Fast to medium (1-20ms)
  • Release: Medium to fast (50-200ms)
  • Makeup Gain: Bring up to match dry signal

Blend Ratio:

  • Dry: 70-90%
  • Compressed: 10-30%
  • Adjust to taste (more compressed = more power, less dynamics)

Why It Works:

  • Preserves transients (dry signal)
  • Adds thickness and sustain (compressed signal)
  • Best of both worlds (dynamic + powerful)
  • Natural + controlled

Applications:

  • Drums: Classic use (especially famous on drum room mics)
  • Vocals: Powerful but natural
  • Bass: Thick but dynamic
  • Mix bus: Subtle glue without over-compression

Famous Example: Chris Lord-Alge (engineer) popularized in 1980s-90s. Called "New York Compression" due to NYC studio origins.

intermediate.title: Identify: Serial Compression (Stacked/Multiple)
intermediate.content: Which term best describes: "Using multiple compressors in series (one after another) with gentle settings."?
intermediate.explanation:
Serial Compression (Stacked/Multiple)

Using multiple compressors in series (one after another) with gentle settings.

Concept:

  • Compressor 1: First stage (3-4dB reduction)
  • Compressor 2: Second stage (3-4dB reduction)
  • Total: 6-8dB reduction, but smoother than single compressor

Why Multiple Compressors:

  • Each compressor works less hard
  • More transparent (smaller gain reduction per stage)
  • Different characters combine
  • More natural than heavy single compression

Typical Chain:

  • Stage 1: Fast compressor (FET) - control peaks (2-3dB)
  • Stage 2: Smooth compressor (optical) - even out body (3-4dB)
  • Stage 3: Final glue (VCA on mix bus) - final control (1-2dB)

Common Combinations:

  • 1176 → LA-2A: FET peaks, optical smoothing (classic vocal chain)
  • Fast VCA → Slow VCA: Peaks then body
  • API 2500 → SSL Bus: Two VCAs, different characters
  • Plugin chains: Multiple plugins, different characters

Applications:

  • Vocals: Multiple gentle stages (more natural than single heavy)
  • Mix bus: Gentle compression at multiple points
  • Mastering: Typically 2-3 stages of gentle compression

Professional Practice: Each stage 3-4dB maximum. Total 6-12dB across chain. More transparent than 12dB from single compressor.

---

intermediate.title: Identify: FET Compressor (Field Effect Transistor)
intermediate.content: Which term best describes: "Fast, aggressive compression using FET transistor circuit."?
intermediate.explanation:
FET Compressor (Field Effect Transistor)

Fast, aggressive compression using FET transistor circuit.

Technology:

  • Field Effect Transistor controls gain
  • Ultra-fast response (microseconds)
  • All-button-in mode (1176)
  • Harmonic distortion adds character

Characteristics:

  • Ultra-fast attack: Fastest compressor type (20-800µs on 1176)
  • Aggressive character: Adds punch and excitement
  • Harmonic color: Warm distortion, especially when pushed
  • Limited controls: Often simpler interface
  • Best on transients: Drums, percussion, plucked instruments

Famous FET Compressors:

  • Universal Audio 1176: Industry legend since 1967, ultra-fast, all-buttons-in mode, vocals/drums/bass standard, $2,500-4,000 (reissue), $5,000+ (vintage Rev A/E)
  • Empirical Labs Distressor: Modern FET, extremely versatile, "Brit Mode," $2,000-2,500
  • Purple Audio MC77: 1176 clone, high quality, $1,800

1176 Characteristics:

  • Fastest attack: 20µs to 800µs (microseconds!)
  • Four ratios: 4:1, 8:1, 12:1, 20:1
  • All-buttons-in: Press all ratio buttons = aggressive, distinctive sound (not true ratio)
  • Inverse controls: Clockwise = less compression (vintage quirk)
  • Character: Punchy, aggressive, adds excitement

All-Buttons-In Mode (1176):

  • Cult following effect
  • Not designed feature (discovered by users)
  • Approximately 12:1 ratio with unique distortion
  • Very aggressive, exciting sound
  • Famous on drums (room mics), bass, electric guitar

Sound Character:

  • Aggressive, forward, in-your-face
  • Adds punch and presence
  • Harmonic excitement
  • "Larger than life" quality

Best For:

  • Vocals (aggressive, present, cutting through mix)
  • Drums (snare, room mics - punchy and aggressive)
  • Bass (tight, forward, controlled)
  • Electric guitar (add punch)
  • Anything needing attitude

Professional Use: Go-to for vocals in rock/pop. 1176 most recorded-through compressor in history. Classic on snare drum, bass, rock vocals.

---

intermediate.title: Identify: Variable-Mu Compressor (Tube)
intermediate.content: Which term best describes: "Vintage tube compressor using tube gain reduction."?
intermediate.explanation:
Variable-Mu Compressor (Tube)

Vintage tube compressor using tube gain reduction.

Technology:

  • Vacuum tubes (valves)
  • Tube bias controlled by input signal
  • Changes tube's amplification factor (mu)
  • All-tube signal path
  • Transformer-coupled

Characteristics:

  • Smooth, gentle compression: Very musical
  • Slow attack: Natural, transparent
  • Harmonic coloration: Tube warmth and saturation
  • Expensive: Tubes, transformers, complex circuit
  • Heavy: Large iron transformers
  • High maintenance: Tubes need replacement

Famous Variable-Mu Compressors:

  • Fairchild 670: Holy grail of compressors, 1959 design, 65 pounds, 20 tubes, $30,000-60,000+ (original vintage), $10,000-15,000 (modern reissues)
  • Manley Variable Mu: Modern classic, stereo, $4,200
  • Pendulum OCL-2: High-end modern, $6,000

Fairchild 670 Characteristics:

  • Stereo: Two channels, can be linked
  • Variable threshold: 6 threshold positions
  • Time constants: 6 settings (attack/release combinations)
  • Transformers: Input and output transformers (character)
  • Weight: 65 pounds! (massive iron)
  • Sound: Ultimate smooth, glue, warmth

Sound Character:

  • Smoothest compression available
  • Thick, warm, 3D quality
  • "Glue" effect on mix
  • Harmonic richness
  • Vintage, classic sound

Best For:

  • Mix bus (ultimate glue)
  • Mastering (smooth, transparent)
  • Vocals (warm, smooth)
  • Anything needing vintage character
  • High-end productions

Why So Expensive:

  • Complex tube circuit (20 tubes in 670)
  • Large transformers (expensive, heavy)
  • Vintage units rare (high demand)
  • Modern reissues still expensive (parts, labor)

Professional Use: Mix bus compression on high-end albums. Mastering. When budget allows and need ultimate smoothness. Beatles, Led Zeppelin used Fairchild 670.

---

intermediate.title: Identify: VCA Compressor (Voltage Controlled Amplifier)
intermediate.content: Which term best describes: "Modern, clean, precise compression using solid-state VCA chip."?
intermediate.explanation:
VCA Compressor (Voltage Controlled Amplifier)

Modern, clean, precise compression using solid-state VCA chip.

Technology:

  • Voltage controlled amplifier circuit
  • VCA chip (dbx, THAT, SSM) controls gain
  • Fast, accurate response
  • Clean, transparent (or colored by design)

Characteristics:

  • Fast attack/release: Can be extremely fast (<0.1ms attack)
  • Precise control: Accurate ratio and threshold
  • Versatile: Works on any source material
  • Clean or colored: Design-dependent (SSL colored, dbx clean)
  • Punchy: Excellent transient control

Famous VCA Compressors:

  • SSL Bus Compressor (G-Series): Industry standard mix bus, punchy, glue, 4:1 ratio with auto-release, $3,000-8,000
  • dbx 160: Clean, precise, broadcast/live, $500-800
  • API 2500: Stereo bus, three compression "knees," punchy, $2,500-3,200
  • Neve 33609: British character, smooth, mix bus, $6,000-8,000

Sound Character:

  • SSL: Punchy, aggressive, forward (rock, pop)
  • dbx: Clean, transparent, utility
  • API: Punchy, thick, musical (all genres)
  • Neve: Smooth, warm, gentle (classic)

Best For:

  • Mix bus compression (SSL, API)
  • Drums (punchy, fast)
  • Bass (tight, controlled)
  • Versatile all-around use

Attack/Release:

  • Can be very fast (instant peak control)
  • Or slow (gentle compression)
  • Full range of speeds available

Modern Standard: Most common type in modern production. Found in every studio.

---

advanced.title: Concept: Variable-Mu Compressor (Tube)
advanced.content: True or False: Variable-Mu Compressor (Tube) is defined as: Opposite of compressor - increases dynamic range.
advanced.explanation:
Variable-Mu Compressor (Tube)

Vintage tube compressor using tube gain reduction.

Technology:

advanced.title: Concept: VCA Compressor (Voltage Controlled Amplifier)
advanced.content: True or False: VCA Compressor (Voltage Controlled Amplifier) is defined as: Time compressor takes to react after signal exceeds threshold.
advanced.explanation:
VCA Compressor (Voltage Controlled Amplifier)

Modern, clean, precise compression using solid-state VCA chip.

Technology:

  • Voltage controlled amplifier circuit
  • VCA chip (dbx, THAT, SSM) controls gain
  • Fast, accurate response
  • Clean, transparent (or colored by design)

Characteristics:

  • Fast attack/release: Can be extremely fast (<0.1ms attack)
  • Precise control: Accurate ratio and threshold
  • Versatile: Works on any source material
  • Clean or colored: Design-dependent (SSL colored, dbx clean)
  • Punchy: Excellent transient control

Famous VCA Compressors:

  • SSL Bus Compressor (G-Series): Industry standard mix bus, punchy, glue, 4:1 ratio with auto-release, $3,000-8,000
  • dbx 160: Clean, precise, broadcast/live, $500-800
  • API 2500: Stereo bus, three compression "knees," punchy, $2,500-3,200
  • Neve 33609: British character, smooth, mix bus, $6,000-8,000

Sound Character:

  • SSL: Punchy, aggressive, forward (rock, pop)
  • dbx: Clean, transparent, utility
  • API: Punchy, thick, musical (all genres)
  • Neve: Smooth, warm, gentle (classic)

Best For:

  • Mix bus compression (SSL, API)
  • Drums (punchy, fast)
  • Bass (tight, controlled)
  • Versatile all-around use

Attack/Release:

  • Can be very fast (instant peak control)
  • Or slow (gentle compression)
