advanced.title: Concept: Upward Compression
advanced.content: True or False: Upward Compression is defined as: Raising quieter parts instead of lowering louder parts (opposite of normal compression).
advanced.explanation:
Upward Compression

Raising quieter parts instead of lowering louder parts (opposite of normal compression).

Concept:

  • Normal compression: lowers peaks above threshold
  • Upward compression: raises quiet parts below threshold
  • Reduces dynamic range from bottom up (not top down)
  • Final result similar, but process opposite

When to Use:

  • Detailed, quiet passages need boosting
  • Want to preserve peak dynamics
  • Bring up room sound, ambience
  • Enhance sustain and decay tails

Difference from Normal Compression:

  • Normal: Makes loud quieter (subtractive)
  • Upward: Makes quiet louder (additive)
  • Can be less audible (preserves peaks)

Applications:

  • Enhancing quiet details
  • Bringing up room ambience
  • Less common (most compressors don't offer)
  • More common in mastering

Available In:

  • Some mastering processors
  • Specialized plugins (DMG Limitless, Pro-C 2)
  • Less common than downward

---

[Content continues in Part 3 with Limiting, Gates, Expanders, and De-essers]

advanced.title: Concept: Optical Compressor
advanced.content: True or False: Optical Compressor is defined as: External signal controls gate (not input signal).
advanced.explanation:
Optical Compressor

Smooth, natural compression using light-dependent resistor (photo-cell).

Technology:

  • Light source (LED or electroluminescent panel)
  • Photoresistor (light-dependent resistor)
  • Signal controls light intensity
  • Light controls resistance
  • Resistance controls gain
  • Physical lag creates character

Characteristics:

  • Slow, smooth attack: Physical lag (no instant response)
  • Program-dependent release: Faster for fast material, slower for sustained
  • Natural, musical: Most transparent, least obvious
  • Impossible to over-compress: Smooth even at extreme settings
  • Warm character: Gentle harmonic enhancement
  • Slow response: Not good for fast transients (use FET or VCA)

Famous Optical Compressors:

  • Teletronix LA-2A: Legendary since 1965, T4 optical cell, tube makeup amp, vocal standard #1 choice worldwide, $3,000-4,500 (reissue), $8,000+ (vintage)
  • Teletronix LA-3A: Solid-state version, slightly faster, $2,500-3,500
  • Tube-Tech CL 1B: Modern optical, tube, $2,800
  • Manley ELOP: Variable-mu/optical hybrid, expensive, $3,300

LA-2A Characteristics:

  • Fixed ratio: Approximately 3:1 (program-dependent)
  • Two knobs: Peak Reduction (threshold), Gain (makeup)
  • Simple to use: Almost impossible to make sound bad
  • Smooth compression: Very musical, transparent
  • T4 optical cell: Unique slow release characteristic
  • Tube makeup gain: Warmth and character

Program-Dependent Release:

  • Fast material (drums): faster release (avoids pumping)
  • Sustained material (vocals): slower release (smooth)
  • Automatic - no control needed
  • One reason LA-2A sounds so good

Sound Character:

  • Smooth, warm, gentle
  • Transparent even with heavy compression
  • Natural-sounding
  • "Invisible" compression
  • Musical, never harsh

Best For:

  • Vocals (absolute standard, every genre)
  • Bass (smooth, warm, controlled)
  • Acoustic instruments (transparent)
  • Mix bus (gentle glue, invisible)
  • Anything needing smooth, natural compression

Why LA-2A is #1 Vocal Compressor:

  • Simple (two knobs - hard to get wrong)
  • Smooth (never harsh or aggressive)
  • Musical (program-dependent release)
  • Character (tube and optical warmth)
  • Forgiving (hard to over-compress)

Professional Use: LA-2A on lead vocals is studio standard worldwide. Found in every professional studio. Smooth bass compression. Gentle mix bus glue.

---

advanced.title: Concept: Parallel Compression (New York Compression)
advanced.content: True or False: Parallel Compression (New York Compression) is defined as: Blending heavily compressed signal with dry uncompressed signal.
advanced.explanation:
Parallel Compression (New York Compression)

Blending heavily compressed signal with dry uncompressed signal.

Concept: 1. Original signal sent to two paths 2. Path 1: Dry, uncompressed (natural dynamics) 3. Path 2: Heavily compressed (10-20dB reduction, aggressive) 4. Both paths mixed together 5. Result: punch of dry + power of compressed

Setup:

  • Aux send method: Send to aux track with compressor, blend
  • Duplicate track: Duplicate, compress copy, blend
  • Parallel knob: Some compressors have built-in dry/wet blend

Compression Settings for Parallel:

  • Ratio: 10:1 or higher (very aggressive)
  • Threshold: Low (lots of compression, 15-20dB reduction)
  • Attack: Fast to medium (1-20ms)
  • Release: Medium to fast (50-200ms)
  • Makeup Gain: Bring up to match dry signal

Blend Ratio:

  • Dry: 70-90%
  • Compressed: 10-30%
  • Adjust to taste (more compressed = more power, less dynamics)

Why It Works:

  • Preserves transients (dry signal)
  • Adds thickness and sustain (compressed signal)
  • Best of both worlds (dynamic + powerful)
  • Natural + controlled

Applications:

  • Drums: Classic use (especially famous on drum room mics)
  • Vocals: Powerful but natural
  • Bass: Thick but dynamic
  • Mix bus: Subtle glue without over-compression

Famous Example: Chris Lord-Alge (engineer) popularized in 1980s-90s. Called "New York Compression" due to NYC studio origins.

---

advanced.title: Concept: FET Compressor (Field Effect Transistor)
advanced.content: True or False: FET Compressor (Field Effect Transistor) is defined as: How quickly limiter stops limiting after peak passes.
advanced.explanation:
FET Compressor (Field Effect Transistor)

Fast, aggressive compression using FET transistor circuit.

Technology:

  • Field Effect Transistor controls gain
  • Ultra-fast response (microseconds)
  • All-button-in mode (1176)
  • Harmonic distortion adds character

Characteristics:

  • Ultra-fast attack: Fastest compressor type (20-800µs on 1176)
  • Aggressive character: Adds punch and excitement
  • Harmonic color: Warm distortion, especially when pushed
  • Limited controls: Often simpler interface
  • Best on transients: Drums, percussion, plucked instruments

Famous FET Compressors:

  • Universal Audio 1176: Industry legend since 1967, ultra-fast, all-buttons-in mode, vocals/drums/bass standard, $2,500-4,000 (reissue), $5,000+ (vintage Rev A/E)
  • Empirical Labs Distressor: Modern FET, extremely versatile, "Brit Mode," $2,000-2,500
  • Purple Audio MC77: 1176 clone, high quality, $1,800

1176 Characteristics:

  • Fastest attack: 20µs to 800µs (microseconds!)
  • Four ratios: 4:1, 8:1, 12:1, 20:1
  • All-buttons-in: Press all ratio buttons = aggressive, distinctive sound (not true ratio)
  • Inverse controls: Clockwise = less compression (vintage quirk)
  • Character: Punchy, aggressive, adds excitement

All-Buttons-In Mode (1176):

  • Cult following effect
  • Not designed feature (discovered by users)
  • Approximately 12:1 ratio with unique distortion
  • Very aggressive, exciting sound
  • Famous on drums (room mics), bass, electric guitar

Sound Character:

  • Aggressive, forward, in-your-face
  • Adds punch and presence
  • Harmonic excitement
  • "Larger than life" quality

Best For:

  • Vocals (aggressive, present, cutting through mix)
  • Drums (snare, room mics - punchy and aggressive)
  • Bass (tight, forward, controlled)
  • Electric guitar (add punch)
  • Anything needing attitude

Professional Use: Go-to for vocals in rock/pop. 1176 most recorded-through compressor in history. Classic on snare drum, bass, rock vocals.

---

advanced.title: Concept: Digital Compressor
advanced.content: True or False: Digital Compressor is defined as: Amount of attenuation when gate closed.
advanced.explanation:
Digital Compressor

Software-based or DSP-based compression with mathematical precision.

Technology:

  • Purely mathematical algorithms
  • No analog circuitry
  • Can model any compressor type
  • Perfect recall
  • Consistent (no component drift)

Characteristics:

  • Clean: No analog noise or distortion (unless modeled)
  • Precise: Perfect ratio and threshold
  • Flexible: Any attack/release time
  • Visual feedback: Detailed metering and graphs
  • Consistent: Sounds same every time
  • Affordable: Software plugins vs hardware

Types of Digital Compressors:

Transparent/Clean:

  • FabFilter Pro-C 2 (extremely versatile, visual feedback)
  • DMG Limitless (modern, precise)
  • Stock DAW compressors (Logic, Pro Tools)

Analog Modeling:

  • Universal Audio 1176 plugin (models FET)
  • Waves CLA-2A (models LA-2A optical)
  • Slate VBC (models vintage compressors)
  • Plugin Alliance SSL, API, Neve (model VCA)

Advantages:

  • Unlimited instances (hardware = one unit)
  • Perfect recall (save/load settings instantly)
  • Visual feedback (see exactly what's happening)
  • Affordable (free to $200 vs $2,000-60,000 hardware)
  • No maintenance (no tubes to replace)

Disadvantages:

  • Can sound sterile (without analog modeling)
  • No tactile interface (mouse vs knobs)
  • CPU usage (many instances = high CPU)
  • Lacks analog "mistakes" (happy accidents)

Best Modern Plugins:

  • FabFilter Pro-C 2: Versatile, visual, $179
  • Waves SSL G-Master: VCA model, $179
  • UAD 1176 Collection: FET model, $299
  • UAD Teletronix LA-2A: Optical model, $299
  • Slate VBC: Multiple vintage models, $149

Professional Use: Digital compression standard in modern production. Mix of stock plugins and analog models. Use clean digital for utility, analog models for character.

---

#

3. Advanced Compression Techniques

advanced.title: Concept: Serial Compression (Stacked/Multiple)
advanced.content: True or False: Serial Compression (Stacked/Multiple) is defined as: Using multiple compressors in series (one after another) with gentle settings.
advanced.explanation:
Serial Compression (Stacked/Multiple)

Using multiple compressors in series (one after another) with gentle settings.

Concept:

  • Compressor 1: First stage (3-4dB reduction)
  • Compressor 2: Second stage (3-4dB reduction)
  • Total: 6-8dB reduction, but smoother than single compressor

Why Multiple Compressors:

  • Each compressor works less hard
  • More transparent (smaller gain reduction per stage)
  • Different characters combine
  • More natural than heavy single compression

Typical Chain:

  • Stage 1: Fast compressor (FET) - control peaks (2-3dB)
  • Stage 2: Smooth compressor (optical) - even out body (3-4dB)
  • Stage 3: Final glue (VCA on mix bus) - final control (1-2dB)

Common Combinations:

  • 1176 → LA-2A: FET peaks, optical smoothing (classic vocal chain)
  • Fast VCA → Slow VCA: Peaks then body
  • API 2500 → SSL Bus: Two VCAs, different characters
  • Plugin chains: Multiple plugins, different characters

Applications:

  • Vocals: Multiple gentle stages (more natural than single heavy)
  • Mix bus: Gentle compression at multiple points
  • Mastering: Typically 2-3 stages of gentle compression

Professional Practice: Each stage 3-4dB maximum. Total 6-12dB across chain. More transparent than 12dB from single compressor.

---

basic.title: Hold Time

answers.text: Vintage tube compressor using tube gain reduction.
Software-based or DSP-based compression with mathematical precision.
Increases dynamics by raising loud parts.
Time gate stays open after signal falls below threshold.

basic.explanation:
Hold Time

Time gate stays open after signal falls below threshold.

Purpose:

  • Prevents chattering (rapid open/close)
  • Keeps gate open through brief dips
  • More natural decay

Settings:

  • 10ms-50ms: Percussive
  • 50ms-200ms: Standard
  • 200ms-1000ms: Long holds

basic.title: Complete: Range/Reduction
basic.content:
Complete the definition for Range/Reduction:
"Amount of attenuation when gate _______"
basic.explanation:
Range/Reduction

Amount of attenuation when gate closed.

Settings:

  • -∞dB: Complete silence (hard gate)
  • -40dB: Gentle reduction (soft gate)
  • -20dB: Moderate reduction

Hard vs Soft Gate:

  • Hard (-∞dB): Complete silence, obvious
  • Soft (-20 to -40dB): Reduces noise, more natural

basic.title: Ducking

answers.text: Peaks between samples occurring during D/A conversion.
Preventing signal from exceeding specific maximum level (ceiling).
External signal controls gate (not input signal).
Reducing level when external signal present (opposite of gating).

basic.explanation:
Ducking

Reducing level when external signal present (opposite of gating).

Example: Lower music when voice present (podcast/radio)

Setup:

  • Sidechain input: voice
  • Gate on music
  • Inverted: closes when voice present

basic.title: True Peak Limiting

answers.text: Fast, aggressive compression using FET transistor circuit.
Accounts for inter-sample peaks that occur during D/A conversion.
Vintage tube compressor using tube gain reduction.
Time compressor takes to return to unity gain after signal drops below threshold.

basic.explanation:
True Peak Limiting

Accounts for inter-sample peaks that occur during D/A conversion.

Inter-Sample Peaks (ISP):

  • Peaks between digital samples
  • Created during reconstruction (D/A conversion)
  • Can exceed 0dBFS digitally
  • Cause: clipping in analog domain

True Peak Measurement:

  • 4x or 8x oversampling
  • Measures what will exist after D/A
  • Measured in dBTP (True Peak)
  • Essential for mastering

Target Levels:

  • -1.0dBTP: Safe for all platforms
  • -0.3dBTP: Aggressive but safe
  • 0dBTP: Risk of analog clipping

Why Important:

  • Prevents clipping during playback
  • Streaming services require (Spotify, Apple Music)
  • Broadcast standards
  • Professional mastering standard

basic.title: Dynamic Range (Complete)

answers.text: Leaving level space before mastering stage.
Difference between loudest and quietest parts of audio.
Blending heavily compressed signal with dry uncompressed signal.

basic.explanation:
Dynamic Range (Complete)

Difference between loudest and quietest parts of audio.

Measurement:

  • In decibels (dB)
  • Peak minus noise floor = maximum possible
  • Crest factor = peak / RMS (program dynamic range)

By Genre:

  • Classical: 20-30dB (very wide)
  • Jazz: 15-25dB (wide)
  • Rock: 10-15dB (moderate)
  • Pop: 6-12dB (narrow)
  • EDM/Hip-Hop: 4-8dB (very narrow)

basic.title: Complete: Expander (Downward)
basic.content:
Complete the definition for Expander (Downward):
"Opposite of compressor - increases _______ range."
basic.explanation:
Expander (Downward)

Opposite of compressor - increases dynamic range.

How It Works:

  • Signal below threshold: reduced further
  • Signal above threshold: passes normally
  • Like gentle gate (reduction not silence)

Ratio:

  • 1:2 typical (opposite of 2:1 compressor)
  • Signal 2dB below threshold = 3dB reduction (1dB more)

Uses:

  • Gentle noise reduction
  • Increase dynamics
  • "Open up" compressed material
  • More natural than gate

basic.title: Complete: Threshold
basic.content:
Complete the definition for Threshold:
"Level below _______ gate closes."
basic.explanation:
Threshold

Level below which gate closes.

Setting:

  • Above noise floor
  • Below desired signal
  • Find balance: silence noise, pass wanted sound

Common Mistake:

  • Too high: cuts off quiet parts of signal
  • Too low: doesn't remove noise

basic.title: Complete: Attack Time (Gate)
basic.content:
Complete the definition for Attack Time (Gate):
"How quickly gate opens when _______ exceeds threshold."
basic.explanation:
Attack Time (Gate)

How quickly gate opens when signal exceeds threshold.

Settings:

  • 0.1ms-1ms: Instant (percussive sounds)
  • 1ms-10ms: Fast (most sounds)
  • 10ms-50ms: Slow (smooth, gentle)

Too Fast: Can click Too Slow: Cuts off attack transient

Typical: 1-5ms for drums, 5-20ms for vocals

basic.title: Complete: Upward Expander
basic.content:
Complete the definition for Upward Expander:
"Increases _______ by raising loud parts."
basic.explanation:
Upward Expander

Increases dynamics by raising loud parts.

Opposite of Upward Compression:

  • Makes loud parts louder
  • Below threshold passes normally
  • Increases dynamic range from top

Rare: Less common, specialized use

basic.title: Complete: Release Time (Limiting)
basic.content:
Complete the definition for Release Time (Limiting):
"How quickly _______ stops limiting after peak passes."
basic.explanation:
Release Time (Limiting)

How quickly limiter stops limiting after peak passes.

Settings:

  • Fast (10-50ms): Follows signal closely, can pump
  • Medium (50-200ms): Balanced, natural
  • Slow (200-1000ms): Smooth, less pumping
  • Auto: Adjusts based on material (most common)

intermediate.title: Identify: Sidechain Compression (Complete)
intermediate.content: Which term best describes: "Using external signal to trigger compression."?
intermediate.explanation:
Sidechain Compression (Complete)

Using external signal to trigger compression.

Setup: 1. Compressor on track A (bass) 2. Sidechain input: track B (kick drum) 3. When kick hits: bass compresses 4. Result: bass "ducks" out of way of kick

Famous Use:

  • Dance music (bass ducks for kick)
  • "Pumping" effect (EDM, house)
  • Creates space for kick
  • Rhythmic, musical

Settings:

  • Fast attack (0.1-5ms)
  • Fast release (50-150ms)
  • Moderate ratio (4:1-8:1)
  • 3-6dB reduction

Applications:

  • Bass/Kick relationship (make room)
  • Vocals/Music (music ducks for vocals)
  • Lead/Pads (pads duck for lead)
  • Rhythmic effects

intermediate.title: Identify: RMS vs Peak Metering
intermediate.content: Which term best describes: "Two different ways to measure audio level."?
intermediate.explanation:
RMS vs Peak Metering

Two different ways to measure audio level.

Peak Meter:

  • Shows instantaneous peak level
  • Catches transient spikes
  • Important: preventing clipping
  • Doesn't represent loudness

RMS Meter (Root Mean Square):

  • Shows average level over time
  • Represents perceived loudness better
  • Slower response
  • Used: for compression, dynamics

Both Important:

  • Watch peaks: prevent clipping
  • Watch RMS: manage loudness and dynamics

intermediate.title: Identify: Sidechain EQ
intermediate.content: Which term best describes: "EQ'd sidechain signal (compress only specific frequencies)."?
intermediate.explanation:
Sidechain EQ

EQ'd sidechain signal (compress only specific frequencies).

Use Case:

  • De-esser (compress only when sibilance present)
  • Frequency-specific ducking
  • Kick only triggers on low frequencies

Setup: 1. High-pass filter on sidechain 2. Only low frequencies trigger 3. More precise control

intermediate.title: Identify: Headroom (Before Mastering)
intermediate.content: Which term best describes: "Leaving level space before mastering stage."?
intermediate.explanation:
Headroom (Before Mastering)

Leaving level space before mastering stage.

Target:

  • -6dBFS on master bus peaks (ideal)
  • -3dBFS minimum
  • Leaves room for mastering processing

Why Needed:

  • Mastering adds level
  • Processing adds level
  • Prevents clipping
  • Allows mastering engineer to work

Common Mistake:

  • Mixing to 0dBFS (no headroom)
  • Mastering engineer can't add anything
  • Must lower level first (reduces quality)

intermediate.title: Identify: Lookahead (Gate)
intermediate.content: Which term best describes: "Gate previews signal to open before transient."?
intermediate.explanation:
Lookahead (Gate)

Gate previews signal to open before transient.

Benefits:

  • Preserves attack transients
  • Gate opens before hit
  • No transient loss
  • Adds latency (1-5ms)

intermediate.title: Identify: Crest Factor
intermediate.content: Which term best describes: "Ratio between peak and RMS level."?
intermediate.explanation:
Crest Factor

Ratio between peak and RMS level.

Formula: Peak (dB) - RMS (dB) = Crest Factor

High Crest Factor (15-20dB):

  • Dynamic material
  • Classical, jazz
  • Lots of peaks, lower average
  • Wide dynamic range

Low Crest Factor (4-8dB):

  • Heavily compressed
  • Modern pop, EDM
  • Peaks close to average
  • Narrow dynamic range

Professional Understanding:

  • High = dynamic, natural
  • Low = compressed, loud
  • Balance based on genre

intermediate.title: Identify: Modern Loudness Targets (LUFS)
intermediate.content: Which term best describes: "Integrated Loudness Units Full Scale."?
intermediate.explanation:
Modern Loudness Targets (LUFS)

Integrated Loudness Units Full Scale.

Streaming Platforms:

  • Spotify: -14 LUFS
  • Apple Music: -16 LUFS (Sound Check)
  • YouTube: -13 to -14 LUFS
  • Amazon Music: -14 LUFS
  • Tidal: -14 LUFS

Broadcasting:

  • European EBU R128: -23 LUFS
  • US ATSC A/85: -24 LKFS (same as LUFS)
  • Broadcast stricter than streaming

Mastering Strategy:

  • Target -14 LUFS for streaming
  • -0.3dBTP ceiling
  • Preserves dynamics
  • Sounds good on all platforms

If Louder Than Target:

  • Platform turns down (reduces quality)
  • Wasted dynamics
  • No benefit to louder

Professional Practice:

  • Master to -14 LUFS integrated
  • -0.3 to -1.0dBTP ceiling
  • Preserve dynamics
  • Don't chase loudness

---

#

5. Noise Gates

intermediate.title: Identify: Attack Time (Gate)
intermediate.content: Which term best describes: "How quickly gate opens when signal exceeds threshold."?
intermediate.explanation:
Attack Time (Gate)

How quickly gate opens when signal exceeds threshold.

Settings:

  • 0.1ms-1ms: Instant (percussive sounds)
  • 1ms-10ms: Fast (most sounds)
  • 10ms-50ms: Slow (smooth, gentle)

Too Fast: Can click Too Slow: Cuts off attack transient

Typical: 1-5ms for drums, 5-20ms for vocals

intermediate.title: Identify: Applications (Gate)
intermediate.content: Which term best describes: "Common uses for noise gates."?
intermediate.explanation:
Applications (Gate)

Common uses for noise gates.

Drum Gating:

  • Remove ring and bleed
  • Tighten sound
  • Control sustain
  • Especially: toms, snare bottom mic

Vocal Gating:

  • Remove breath noise
  • Clean up between phrases
  • Gentle settings (not obvious)

Guitar Amp:

  • Remove hum and noise
  • Between notes/phrases
  • Tight, controlled sound

Live Sound:

  • Reduce feedback potential
  • Clean up monitors
  • Tighten overall sound

---

#

6. Expanders & De-essers

intermediate.title: Identify: Loudness Maximization
intermediate.content: Which term best describes: "Using limiting to achieve competitive loudness."?
intermediate.explanation:
Loudness Maximization

Using limiting to achieve competitive loudness.

Process: 1. Set ceiling (-0.3dBFS) 2. Raise input level 3. Limiter controls peaks 4. Result: louder average level

Loudness Units:

  • LUFS: Loudness Units Full Scale (modern standard)
  • dBFS: Peak level (not loudness)
  • RMS: Average level (older measurement)

Modern Targets:

  • Spotify: -14 LUFS integrated
  • Apple Music: -16 LUFS
  • YouTube: -13 LUFS
  • CD: -8 to -10 LUFS typical

Loudness War:

  • Race to make music louder
  • Heavy limiting, reduced dynamics
  • Listener fatigue
  • Streaming normalized levels (war over)

advanced.title: Concept: Range/Reduction
advanced.content: True or False: Range/Reduction is defined as: Amount of attenuation when gate closed.
advanced.explanation:
Range/Reduction

Amount of attenuation when gate closed.

Settings:

  • -∞dB: Complete silence (hard gate)
  • -40dB: Gentle reduction (soft gate)
  • -20dB: Moderate reduction

Hard vs Soft Gate:

  • Hard (-∞dB): Complete silence, obvious
  • Soft (-20 to -40dB): Reduces noise, more natural

advanced.title: Concept: Creative Sidechain Effects
advanced.content: True or False: Creative Sidechain Effects is defined as: How quickly gate opens when signal exceeds threshold.
advanced.explanation:
Creative Sidechain Effects

Artistic uses beyond utility.

Rhythmic Pumping:

  • EDM/Dance standard
  • Obvious pumping effect
  • Musical, rhythmic
  • Part of genre aesthetic

Gated Reverb:

  • Gate on reverb
  • Triggered by dry signal
  • Classic 80s effect
  • Phil Collins drum sound

Tremolo Effect:

  • LFO triggers sidechain
  • Rhythmic pulsing
  • Tempo-synced

---

#

Summary: Volume 5 Complete

Part 1: Compression Theory - 9 Core Parameters (Threshold, Ratio, Attack, Release, Knee, Makeup Gain, Metering, Input/Output)

Part 2: 7 Compressor Types (VCA, FET, Optical, Variable-Mu, Tube, Diode Bridge, Digital) + Advanced Compression (Parallel, Serial, Upward)

Part 3: Limiting Complete (10 concepts), Noise Gates (11 parameters), Expanders, De-essers

Part 4: Dynamics in Mixing/Mastering (9 concepts: Dynamic Range, Gain Staging, RMS vs Peak, LUFS, Crest Factor, Headroom, etc.) + Sidechain Processing (8 techniques)

Total Coverage: 71 comprehensive entries covering all aspects of dynamic processing from basic compression to advanced mastering techniques.

---

Music Tech Dictionary - Volume 5 of 10 Complete Dynamic Processing Reference © 2024 - Educational Use

advanced.title: Concept: De-esser
advanced.content: True or False: De-esser is defined as: Specialized compressor reducing harsh sibilance (s, t, sh sounds).
advanced.explanation:
De-esser

Specialized compressor reducing harsh sibilance (s, t, sh sounds).

Problem:

  • Sibilance (s, t, sh): 4kHz-10kHz
  • Too loud/harsh in recordings
  • Exaggerated by compression

How It Works: 1. Sidechain filters 4-8kHz (sibilance range) 2. Compressor triggered by filtered signal 3. Reduces overall level when sibilance present 4. Or reduces only 4-8kHz band

Types:

Broadband:

  • Reduces entire signal
  • When sibilance detected
  • Simpler, can sound more natural

Split-band (Multiband):

  • Reduces only sibilant frequencies
  • More precise
  • Can sound more transparent

Sibilance Frequency Range:

  • Male vocals: 4-6kHz
  • Female vocals: 6-8kHz
  • Some extends to 10kHz

Settings:

  • Threshold: -20dB to -10dB (where sibilance occurs)
  • Ratio: 3:1 to 6:1 (moderate to aggressive)
  • Frequency: 4-8kHz (sweep to find sibilance)

De-esser Threshold:

  • Set while vocalist sings "s" sounds
  • Reduce only sibilance (not entire vocal)
  • 3-6dB reduction typical

Professional Practice:

  • Use after compression (compression makes sibilance worse)
  • Gentle reduction (3-6dB)
  • Check doesn't dull overall vocal
  • Essential vocal processing tool

---

PART 4: DYNAMICS IN PRODUCTION

#

7. Dynamics in Mixing & Mastering

advanced.title: Concept: Expander (Downward)
advanced.content: True or False: Expander (Downward) is defined as: Opposite of compressor - increases dynamic range.
advanced.explanation:
Expander (Downward)

Opposite of compressor - increases dynamic range.

How It Works:

  • Signal below threshold: reduced further
  • Signal above threshold: passes normally
  • Like gentle gate (reduction not silence)

Ratio:

  • 1:2 typical (opposite of 2:1 compressor)
  • Signal 2dB below threshold = 3dB reduction (1dB more)

Uses:

  • Gentle noise reduction
  • Increase dynamics
  • "Open up" compressed material
  • More natural than gate

advanced.title: Concept: Dynamic Range (Complete)
advanced.content: True or False: Dynamic Range (Complete) is defined as: Difference between loudest and quietest parts of audio.
advanced.explanation:
Dynamic Range (Complete)

Difference between loudest and quietest parts of audio.

Measurement:

  • In decibels (dB)
  • Peak minus noise floor = maximum possible
  • Crest factor = peak / RMS (program dynamic range)

By Genre:

  • Classical: 20-30dB (very wide)
  • Jazz: 15-25dB (wide)
  • Rock: 10-15dB (moderate)
  • Pop: 6-12dB (narrow)
  • EDM/Hip-Hop: 4-8dB (very narrow)

advanced.title: Concept: Noise Gate Definition
advanced.content: True or False: Noise Gate Definition is defined as: Silences signal when below threshold (opposite of compressor).
advanced.explanation:
Noise Gate Definition

Silences signal when below threshold (opposite of compressor).

Purpose:

  • Remove background noise during silence
  • Eliminate bleed from other sources
  • Clean up recordings
  • Create rhythmic effects

How It Works:

  • Signal below threshold: gate closes (silence)
  • Signal above threshold: gate opens (passes signal)
  • Opposite of compressor (which acts above threshold)

advanced.title: Concept: Sidechain for Ducking
advanced.content: True or False: Sidechain for Ducking is defined as: Maintaining optimal levels for dynamic processors.
advanced.explanation:
Sidechain for Ducking

Automatic volume reduction when other source present.

Podcast/Radio:

  • Music ducks when voice present
  • Automatically
  • Smooth, professional

Setup:

  • Compressor on music
  • Sidechain: microphone
  • Fast attack (1-5ms)
  • Medium release (100-300ms)
  • 6-12dB reduction

advanced.title: Concept: Release Time (Limiting)
advanced.content: True or False: Release Time (Limiting) is defined as: How quickly limiter stops limiting after peak passes.
advanced.explanation:
Release Time (Limiting)

How quickly limiter stops limiting after peak passes.

Settings:

  • Fast (10-50ms): Follows signal closely, can pump
  • Medium (50-200ms): Balanced, natural
  • Slow (200-1000ms): Smooth, less pumping
  • Auto: Adjusts based on material (most common)

advanced.title: Concept: Hysteresis
advanced.content: True or False: Hysteresis is defined as: Different thresholds for opening and closing gate.
advanced.explanation:
Hysteresis

Different thresholds for opening and closing gate.

Opening Threshold: -20dB (example) Closing Threshold: -25dB (5dB lower)

Purpose:

  • Prevents chattering
  • Gate doesn't rapidly open/close
  • More stable behavior

Amount:

  • 3-10dB typical
  • Larger = more stable, less sensitive

advanced.title: Concept: Lookahead (Gate)
advanced.content: True or False: Lookahead (Gate) is defined as: Opposite of compressor - increases dynamic range.
advanced.explanation:
Lookahead (Gate)

Gate previews signal to open before transient.

Benefits:

  • Preserves attack transients
  • Gate opens before hit
  • No transient loss
  • Adds latency (1-5ms)

parts.title: Part 1: EQ Fundamentals, Parameters & Filter Types

basic.title: Complete: Gain/Amplitude (±dB)
basic.content:
Complete the definition for Gain/Amplitude (±dB):
"_______ of boost or cut applied at specific frequency."
basic.explanation:
Gain/Amplitude (±dB)

Amount of boost or cut applied at specific frequency.

Measurement: Decibels (dB)

  • Positive (+dB): Boost (increases level)
  • Negative (-dB): Cut (decreases level)
  • 0dB: No change (unity gain)

Typical Boost/Cut Ranges:

  • Subtle: ±1-3dB (transparent, natural)
  • Moderate: ±3-6dB (noticeable, musical)
  • Aggressive: ±6-12dB (obvious, corrective)
  • Extreme: ±12dB+ (special effects, problem-solving)

Boosting:

  • Adds emphasis to frequencies
  • Can introduce phase shift
  • Reduces headroom (adds level)
  • Use: Enhancement, presence, character
  • Guideline: Boost 1-3dB typical, up to 6dB musical

Cutting:

  • Removes problematic frequencies
  • Less phase shift than boosting
  • Increases headroom (reduces level)
  • Use: Problem-solving, mud removal, harshness reduction
  • Guideline: Cut 3-6dB typical, up to 12dB+ for problems

Professional Philosophy:

  • "Cut to fix, boost to enhance": Cuts solve problems, boosts add character
  • "Make it worse, then better": Boost to find problem, cut to fix
  • "Wide cuts, narrow boosts": General guideline for musical EQ
  • "Less is more": Small moves (1-3dB) often sufficient

Perception:

  • 1dB: Barely noticeable, subtle
  • 3dB: Clearly noticeable
  • 6dB: Very noticeable, significant change
  • 10dB+: Extreme, obvious change

---

basic.title: Complete: High-Pass Filter (HPF) / Low-Cut Filter
basic.content:
Complete the definition for High-Pass Filter (HPF) / Low-Cut Filter:
"_______ frequencies below cutoff point, allows highs to pass."
basic.explanation:
High-Pass Filter (HPF) / Low-Cut Filter

Removes frequencies below cutoff point, allows highs to pass.

Names:

  • High-Pass Filter (HPF): Describes what passes (highs)
  • Low-Cut Filter: Describes what's removed (lows)
  • Both terms: Mean same thing

Cutoff Frequency:

  • Point where signal is -3dB (half power)
  • Frequencies below: Progressively removed
  • Frequencies above: Pass through unaffected

Slope:

  • 6dB/octave (1-pole): Gentle, subtle removal
  • 12dB/octave (2-pole): Moderate, standard (most common)
  • 18dB/octave (3-pole): Steep, aggressive
  • 24dB/octave (4-pole): Very steep, brick-wall
  • Higher slopes: More aggressive removal, more phase shift

Applications:

Vocals:

  • Cutoff: 80-100Hz (removes rumble, plosives, room noise)
  • Slope: 12-18dB/octave
  • Benefit: Cleaner, clearer, more headroom

Guitars:

  • Cutoff: 80-120Hz (removes mud, rumble)
  • Slope: 12dB/octave
  • Benefit: Tighter, clearer low end

Snare Drum:

  • Cutoff: 80-100Hz (removes kick bleed, rumble)
  • Slope: 12-18dB/octave
  • Benefit: Cleaner snare, less mud

Overhead Cymbals:

  • Cutoff: 200-400Hz (removes cymbal wash, mud)
  • Slope: 12-18dB/octave
  • Benefit: Cleaner, brighter cymbals

Mix Bus:

  • Cutoff: 30-40Hz (removes sub-rumble, unnecessary lows)
  • Slope: 12dB/octave
  • Benefit: Tighter, cleaner low end, more headroom

"High-Pass Everything" Rule:

  • Except: Kick drum and bass
  • Removes: Unnecessary low-frequency content
  • Result: Cleaner mix, more headroom, less mud
  • Standard professional practice

Resonance/Q:

  • Some HPF have resonance control
  • Adds: Emphasis at cutoff frequency
  • Can add: Character or thinness
  • Usually: Keep at minimum (flat response)

---

basic.title: Shelf Filter (High-Shelf / Low-Shelf)

answers.text: EQ built into mixing console channels or as dedicated outboard unit.
Boosts or cuts all frequencies above (high-shelf) or below (low-shelf) corner frequency.
Three-dimensional sound space created by two speakers (left and right).
Full control over frequency, gain, and bandwidth (Q) for each band.

basic.explanation:
Shelf Filter (High-Shelf / Low-Shelf)

Boosts or cuts all frequencies above (high-shelf) or below (low-shelf) corner frequency.

Low-Shelf:

  • Affects: All frequencies below corner
  • Flat response: Below corner frequency
  • Transition: At corner frequency
  • Use: Bass boost/cut, warmth control

High-Shelf:

  • Affects: All frequencies above corner
  • Flat response: Above corner frequency
  • Transition: At corner frequency
  • Use: Brightness boost/cut, air control

Parameters:

  • Frequency: Corner/transition frequency
  • Gain: Amount of boost/cut (±dB)
  • Q/Slope: Steepness of transition (optional)

Low-Shelf Applications:

Add Warmth:

  • Frequency: 100-200Hz
  • Gain: +2 to +4dB
  • Use: Vocals, guitars, mix bus

Remove Mud:

  • Frequency: 200-300Hz
  • Gain: -2 to -4dB
  • Use: Guitars, overheads, busses

High-Shelf Applications:

Add Air/Brightness:

  • Frequency: 8-12kHz
  • Gain: +2 to +4dB
  • Use: Vocals, acoustic guitar, mix bus, mastering

Remove Harshness:

  • Frequency: 8-10kHz
  • Gain: -2 to -4dB
  • Use: Harsh sources, digital recordings, mastering

De-essing (Alternative):

  • Frequency: 6-8kHz
  • Gain: -3 to -6dB
  • Use: Sibilant vocals (instead of de-esser)

Q/Slope Control:

  • Low Q: Gentle, musical transition
  • High Q: Sharper, more focused
  • Typical: Q of 0.7-1.0 (moderate)

Shelving vs Bell:

  • Shelf: Affects all frequencies beyond point
  • Bell: Affects narrow band, returns to flat
  • Shelf: More transparent for broad adjustments
  • Bell: Better for specific frequency enhancement

---

basic.title: Center Frequency

answers.text: Exact frequency where EQ boost or cut is centered.
Positioning sound between left and right speakers.
Adjusting balance between mid and sides to control stereo width.
EQ built into mixing console channels or as dedicated outboard unit.

basic.explanation:
Center Frequency

Exact frequency where EQ boost or cut is centered.

Selection:

  • Choose: Based on problem or enhancement goal
  • Sweep: To find resonances or sweetspots
  • Precise: In parametric EQ (20Hz-20kHz range)
  • Fixed: In graphic EQ (predetermined frequencies)

Finding Problem Frequencies: 1. Set large boost (+10dB) 2. Set narrow Q (3-5) 3. Sweep frequency range 4. Listen for harshness, resonance, or problems 5. When found, switch to cut with wider Q

Common Problem Frequencies:

  • 80-120Hz: Boominess in bass/kick
  • 200-400Hz: Muddiness, boxiness
  • 500Hz-1kHz: Honky, nasal quality
  • 2-4kHz: Harshness (electric guitars, vocals)
  • 6-8kHz: Sibilance (vocals)

Enhancement Frequencies:

  • 60-80Hz: Sub-bass weight
  • 100-200Hz: Warmth, body
  • 3-5kHz: Presence, clarity
  • 8-12kHz: Air, brilliance
  • 10-15kHz: Sparkle, sheen

---

basic.title: Complete: Q (Bandwidth/Width)
basic.content:
Complete the definition for Q (Bandwidth/Width):
"Width of frequency band affected by EQ adjustment (Quality _______"
basic.explanation:
Q (Bandwidth/Width)

Width of frequency band affected by EQ adjustment (Quality factor).

Definition:

  • Q = Quality factor
  • Determines: How narrow or wide the EQ band
  • Higher Q: Narrower band (surgical, precise)
  • Lower Q: Wider band (musical, natural)

Q Values:

  • 0.5-0.7: Very wide (multiple octaves, musical, gentle)
  • 1.0-1.5: Moderate width (1-2 octaves, standard)
  • 2.0-5.0: Narrow (1/2-1 octave, corrective)
  • 10+: Very narrow (surgical, notch filter, feedback elimination)

Bandwidth:

  • Alternative to Q (inverse relationship)
  • Measured in octaves
  • Width of affected frequency range
  • Wider bandwidth = lower Q, narrower bandwidth = higher Q

Relationship:

  • Q = 1.41 / Bandwidth (octaves)
  • Example: 1 octave bandwidth = Q of 1.41
  • Example: 2 octave bandwidth = Q of 0.7

When to Use Wide Q (Low Q):

  • Musical EQ (gentle tonal shaping)
  • Broad frequency adjustments
  • Natural-sounding changes
  • Mix bus EQ
  • Mastering
  • Example: Boosting 10kHz with Q 0.7 for "air" (affects 5kHz-20kHz)

When to Use Narrow Q (High Q):

  • Surgical cuts (remove specific resonances)
  • Notch filters (eliminate feedback, hum)
  • Find and remove problems
  • Precise corrections
  • Example: Cutting 3.2kHz with Q 5.0 to remove cabinet resonance

Bell Curve:

  • Shape of parametric EQ boost/cut
  • Peak at center frequency
  • Tapers off on sides
  • Width determined by Q
  • Symmetric around center frequency

Visual:

  • Wide Q (0.5): Gentle hill/valley (affects many frequencies)
  • Medium Q (1.5): Moderate hill/valley (standard)
  • Narrow Q (5.0): Sharp spike/notch (surgical, specific)

Professional Practice:

  • Start wide, narrow as needed
  • Use narrow Q to find problems (sweep with boost)
  • Use wide Q to fix problems (cut with wide Q)
  • Narrow boosts: Can sound unnatural
  • Wide cuts: More musical, transparent

---

basic.title: Low-Pass Filter (LPF) / High-Cut Filter

answers.text: Processing center (mid) and sides separately using M/S encoding/decoding.
Wide, gentle EQ for tonal shaping and enhancement.
Removing problematic frequencies rather than boosting desired ones.
Removes frequencies above cutoff point, allows lows to pass.

basic.explanation:
Low-Pass Filter (LPF) / High-Cut Filter

Removes frequencies above cutoff point, allows lows to pass.

Names:

  • Low-Pass Filter (LPF): Describes what passes (lows)
  • High-Cut Filter: Describes what's removed (highs)
  • Both terms: Mean same thing

Cutoff Frequency:

  • Point where signal is -3dB
  • Frequencies above: Progressively removed
  • Frequencies below: Pass through unaffected

Slope:

  • Same as HPF: 6, 12, 18, 24 dB/octave
  • Steeper slope: More aggressive high-frequency removal

Applications:

Bass Guitar:

  • Cutoff: 5-8kHz (removes pick noise, string noise)
  • Slope: 6-12dB/octave
  • Benefit: Smoother, less harsh highs

Kick Drum:

  • Cutoff: 8-10kHz (removes beater click if too much)
  • Slope: 6-12dB/octave (gentle)
  • Benefit: Smooth, not clicky

Synthesizers:

  • Cutoff: Variable (subtractive synthesis)
  • Slope: 12-24dB/octave
  • Benefit: Tone shaping, warmth, character

De-harshing:

  • Cutoff: 12-16kHz (reduce brittle harshness)
  • Slope: 6dB/octave (gentle)
  • Benefit: Smoother, less fatiguing

"Tape" Effect:

  • Cutoff: 15-18kHz (simulate analog tape)
  • Slope: 6-12dB/octave
  • Benefit: Warmth, vintage character, "analog" sound

Less Common Than HPF:

  • Most instruments: Benefit from highs
  • HPF used more frequently
  • LPF: More specialized applications

---

basic.title: Complete: Bell Filter (Parametric Peak/Dip)
basic.content:
Complete the definition for Bell Filter (Parametric Peak/Dip):
"Boost or cut _______ at specific frequency with adjustable width (Q)."
basic.explanation:
Bell Filter (Parametric Peak/Dip)

Boost or cut centered at specific frequency with adjustable width (Q).

Most Versatile EQ Type:

  • Full control: Frequency, gain, Q
  • Can boost or cut
  • Can be wide or narrow
  • Standard in parametric EQ

Parameters:

  • Frequency: Center of boost/cut
  • Gain: Amount of boost/cut (±dB)
  • Q: Width of affected band

Applications:

  • Most common EQ type
  • Surgical corrections (narrow Q)
  • Musical enhancements (wide Q)
  • Problem-solving
  • Creative shaping

Shape:

  • Bell curve (Gaussian)
  • Peak at center frequency
  • Tapers symmetrically on sides
  • Width determined by Q

---

[Content continues in Part 2 with EQ Types, Techniques, and Applications]

basic.title: Band-Pass Filter

answers.text: Allows frequencies in specific band to pass, removes frequencies above and below.
Traditional EQ with natural phase shift (most common type).
Separate EQ for center (mid) and sides (stereo) information.
Processing center (mid) and sides separately using M/S encoding/decoding.

basic.explanation:
Band-Pass Filter

Allows frequencies in specific band to pass, removes frequencies above and below.

Combination:

  • HPF + LPF = Band-Pass
  • Low cutoff: Removes lows (HPF)
  • High cutoff: Removes highs (LPF)
  • Middle frequencies: Pass through

Parameters:

  • Center frequency: Middle of passed band
  • Bandwidth: Width of passed band (Q)
  • Gain: Optional boost/cut of band

Applications:

Telephone Effect:

  • Low cutoff: 300Hz
  • High cutoff: 3kHz
  • Bandwidth: Narrow (telephone frequency range)
  • Use: Special effect, lo-fi vocal

Isolating Frequency Range:

  • Focus on: Specific frequency problem
  • Remove: Everything else
  • Example: Find and fix 500Hz mud

Creative Effects:

  • "Underwater" sound
  • Walkie-talkie effect
  • Vintage/lo-fi character
  • Extreme filtering

Resonance:

  • Some band-pass: Have resonance control
  • Emphasis: At center frequency
  • Can create: Vowel-like, formant quality

---

basic.title: Complete: Phase Shift (EQ)
basic.content:
Complete the definition for Phase Shift (EQ):
"Change in timing relationship between frequencies _______ by EQ."
basic.explanation:
Phase Shift (EQ)

Change in timing relationship between frequencies caused by EQ.

What Happens:

  • All EQ creates phase shift
  • Different frequencies delayed by different amounts
  • Boosting: More phase shift than cutting
  • Minimum-phase EQ: Standard behavior
  • Linear-phase EQ: No phase shift (but pre-ringing)

Minimum-Phase EQ (Standard):

  • Natural EQ behavior
  • Phase shift increases with boost/cut amount
  • Phase shift increases with Q
  • Can affect stereo image slightly
  • Can cause cancellation when summed to mono
  • More "analog" sounding
  • No pre-ringing

Linear-Phase EQ:

  • Digital-only (impossible in analog)
  • No phase shift (maintains phase relationships)
  • Perfect mono compatibility
  • Better for mastering (stereo image preserved)
  • Causes pre-ringing (energy before transient)
  • More CPU intensive
  • Can sound less natural on drums

When Phase Matters:

  • Multi-mic recordings (drums)
  • Stereo recordings
  • Mastering (maintain stereo image)
  • Mono compatibility

When Phase Doesn't Matter:

  • Single-mic recordings
  • Mono sources
  • Creative EQ (character)

Professional Practice:

  • Use minimum-phase for most mixing
  • Use linear-phase for mastering or stereo material
  • Trust your ears (phase shift often not audible issue)

---

#

2. Filter Types

basic.title: Frequency (Hz/kHz)

answers.text: Visual display showing phase relationship between left and right channels.
Traditional EQ with natural phase shift (most common type).
Pitch of sound measured in Hertz (cycles per second).
Analyzing and copying frequency response from one source to another.

basic.explanation:
Frequency (Hz/kHz)

Pitch of sound measured in Hertz (cycles per second).

Hearing Range: 20Hz to 20,000Hz (20kHz)

  • Reduces with age and hearing damage
  • Most critical range: 200Hz-5kHz (speech, fundamentals)

Frequency Perception:

  • Logarithmic: Each octave doubles frequency
  • Musical intervals: A4 = 440Hz, A5 = 880Hz (octave)
  • Equal spacing: On EQ display represents octaves, not Hz

Key Frequency Regions:

20-60Hz (Sub-Bass):

  • Characteristics: Felt more than heard, rumble, weight
  • Sources: Kick drum fundamental, bass synth low end, 808 bass
  • Too much: Muddy, boomy, wastes headroom
  • Too little: Thin, lacks power and weight
  • Mixing: High-pass most instruments here

60-250Hz (Bass):

  • Characteristics: Warmth, body, fundamental bass
  • Sources: Bass guitar, kick drum, low toms, male vocals
  • Too much: Muddy, unclear, boomy mix
  • Too little: Thin, weak, lacks warmth
  • Critical: For fullness and power

250-500Hz (Low-Mids):

  • Characteristics: Body, warmth, can accumulate (mud)
  • Sources: Guitars, snare body, vocals, piano
  • Too much: Muddy, boxy, undefined mix
  • Too little: Hollow, thin, weak
  • Most problematic: Frequency range (mud zone)

500Hz-2kHz (Mids):

  • Characteristics: Presence, body, honky if too much
  • Sources: Vocals, guitars, snare, most instruments
  • Too much: Honky, nasal, harsh
  • Too little: Distant, recessed, weak
  • Where most fundamental: frequencies live

2-4kHz (Upper-Mids):

  • Characteristics: Clarity, definition, presence, attack
  • Sources: Vocal consonants, snare crack, guitar pick
  • Too much: Harsh, fatiguing, aggressive
  • Too little: Dull, distant, undefined
  • Essential: For clarity and intelligibility

4-6kHz (Presence):

  • Characteristics: Articulation, intelligibility, edge
  • Sources: Vocal sibilance (s, t), cymbal attack, strings
  • Too much: Harsh, sibilant, painful
  • Too little: Dull, muffled, unclear
  • Most sensitive: Human hearing (ear protection!)

6-20kHz (Brilliance/Air):

  • Characteristics: Sparkle, air, space, detail, shimmer
  • Sources: Cymbals, hi-hats, vocal breath, acoustic detail
  • Too much: Harsh, brittle, sibilant
  • Too little: Dull, dark, closed-in
  • Adds: Openness and space to mix

---

intermediate.title: Identify: Band-Pass Filter
intermediate.content: Which term best describes: "Allows frequencies in specific band to pass, removes frequencies above and below."?
intermediate.explanation:
Band-Pass Filter

Allows frequencies in specific band to pass, removes frequencies above and below.

Combination:

  • HPF + LPF = Band-Pass
  • Low cutoff: Removes lows (HPF)
  • High cutoff: Removes highs (LPF)
  • Middle frequencies: Pass through

Parameters:

  • Center frequency: Middle of passed band
  • Bandwidth: Width of passed band (Q)
  • Gain: Optional boost/cut of band

Applications:

Telephone Effect:

  • Low cutoff: 300Hz
  • High cutoff: 3kHz
  • Bandwidth: Narrow (telephone frequency range)
  • Use: Special effect, lo-fi vocal

Isolating Frequency Range:

  • Focus on: Specific frequency problem
  • Remove: Everything else
  • Example: Find and fix 500Hz mud

Creative Effects:

  • "Underwater" sound
  • Walkie-talkie effect
  • Vintage/lo-fi character
  • Extreme filtering

Resonance:

  • Some band-pass: Have resonance control
  • Emphasis: At center frequency
  • Can create: Vowel-like, formant quality

---

intermediate.title: Identify: Phase Shift (EQ)
intermediate.content: Which term best describes: "Change in timing relationship between frequencies caused by EQ."?
intermediate.explanation:
Phase Shift (EQ)

Change in timing relationship between frequencies caused by EQ.

What Happens:

  • All EQ creates phase shift
  • Different frequencies delayed by different amounts
  • Boosting: More phase shift than cutting
  • Minimum-phase EQ: Standard behavior
  • Linear-phase EQ: No phase shift (but pre-ringing)

Minimum-Phase EQ (Standard):

  • Natural EQ behavior
  • Phase shift increases with boost/cut amount
  • Phase shift increases with Q
  • Can affect stereo image slightly
  • Can cause cancellation when summed to mono
  • More "analog" sounding
  • No pre-ringing

Linear-Phase EQ:

  • Digital-only (impossible in analog)
  • No phase shift (maintains phase relationships)
  • Perfect mono compatibility
  • Better for mastering (stereo image preserved)
  • Causes pre-ringing (energy before transient)
  • More CPU intensive
  • Can sound less natural on drums

When Phase Matters:

  • Multi-mic recordings (drums)
  • Stereo recordings
  • Mastering (maintain stereo image)
  • Mono compatibility

When Phase Doesn't Matter:

  • Single-mic recordings
  • Mono sources
  • Creative EQ (character)

Professional Practice:

  • Use minimum-phase for most mixing
  • Use linear-phase for mastering or stereo material
  • Trust your ears (phase shift often not audible issue)

---

#

2. Filter Types

intermediate.title: Identify: Q (Bandwidth/Width)
intermediate.content: Which term best describes: "Width of frequency band affected by EQ adjustment (Quality factor)."?
intermediate.explanation:
Q (Bandwidth/Width)

Width of frequency band affected by EQ adjustment (Quality factor).

Definition:

  • Q = Quality factor
  • Determines: How narrow or wide the EQ band
  • Higher Q: Narrower band (surgical, precise)
  • Lower Q: Wider band (musical, natural)

Q Values:

  • 0.5-0.7: Very wide (multiple octaves, musical, gentle)
  • 1.0-1.5: Moderate width (1-2 octaves, standard)
  • 2.0-5.0: Narrow (1/2-1 octave, corrective)
  • 10+: Very narrow (surgical, notch filter, feedback elimination)

Bandwidth:

  • Alternative to Q (inverse relationship)
  • Measured in octaves
  • Width of affected frequency range
  • Wider bandwidth = lower Q, narrower bandwidth = higher Q

Relationship:

  • Q = 1.41 / Bandwidth (octaves)
  • Example: 1 octave bandwidth = Q of 1.41
  • Example: 2 octave bandwidth = Q of 0.7

When to Use Wide Q (Low Q):

  • Musical EQ (gentle tonal shaping)
  • Broad frequency adjustments
  • Natural-sounding changes
  • Mix bus EQ
  • Mastering
  • Example: Boosting 10kHz with Q 0.7 for "air" (affects 5kHz-20kHz)

When to Use Narrow Q (High Q):

  • Surgical cuts (remove specific resonances)
  • Notch filters (eliminate feedback, hum)
  • Find and remove problems
  • Precise corrections
  • Example: Cutting 3.2kHz with Q 5.0 to remove cabinet resonance

Bell Curve:

  • Shape of parametric EQ boost/cut
  • Peak at center frequency
  • Tapers off on sides
  • Width determined by Q
  • Symmetric around center frequency

Visual:

  • Wide Q (0.5): Gentle hill/valley (affects many frequencies)
  • Medium Q (1.5): Moderate hill/valley (standard)
  • Narrow Q (5.0): Sharp spike/notch (surgical, specific)

Professional Practice:

  • Start wide, narrow as needed
  • Use narrow Q to find problems (sweep with boost)
  • Use wide Q to fix problems (cut with wide Q)
  • Narrow boosts: Can sound unnatural
  • Wide cuts: More musical, transparent

---

intermediate.title: Identify: Equalization (EQ) Definition
intermediate.content: Which term best describes: "Selective boosting or cutting of specific frequencies to shape tonal balance."?
intermediate.explanation:
Equalization (EQ) Definition

Selective boosting or cutting of specific frequencies to shape tonal balance.

Purpose:

  • Corrective: Fix problems (remove resonances, mud, harshness)
  • Creative: Enhance character (add brightness, warmth, presence)
  • Separation: Make elements distinct in mix (carve space)
  • Balance: Create cohesive frequency spectrum across mix

What EQ Does:

  • Boosts: Increases amplitude of specific frequencies
  • Cuts: Decreases amplitude of specific frequencies
  • Filters: Removes frequencies above or below certain point
  • Shapes: Overall tonal balance and character

Types of EQ:

  • Parametric: Full control (frequency, gain, Q)
  • Graphic: Fixed frequencies, fader-based
  • Shelving: Boosts/cuts all frequencies above/below point
  • Filters: Removes frequencies (high-pass, low-pass)
  • Dynamic: Frequency-dependent compression

Frequency Ranges:

  • Sub-bass: 20-60Hz (rumble, weight, power)
  • Bass: 60-250Hz (fundamental low end, warmth, body)
  • Low-mids: 250-500Hz (body, warmth, can be muddy)
  • Mids: 500Hz-2kHz (presence, body, clarity)
  • Upper-mids: 2-4kHz (presence, attack, definition)
  • Presence: 4-6kHz (clarity, articulation, intelligibility)
  • Brilliance: 6-20kHz (air, sparkle, space, detail)

EQ Workflow:

  • Subtractive first: Cut problems before boosting
  • Wide cuts, narrow boosts: General mixing guideline
  • High-pass everything: Except kick and bass
  • Context matters: Solo vs mix context
  • Small moves: 1-3dB changes significant

---

intermediate.title: Identify: Shelf Filter (High-Shelf / Low-Shelf)
intermediate.content: Which term best describes: "Boosts or cuts all frequencies above (high-shelf) or below (low-shelf) corner frequency."?
intermediate.explanation:
Shelf Filter (High-Shelf / Low-Shelf)

Boosts or cuts all frequencies above (high-shelf) or below (low-shelf) corner frequency.

Low-Shelf:

  • Affects: All frequencies below corner
  • Flat response: Below corner frequency
  • Transition: At corner frequency
  • Use: Bass boost/cut, warmth control

High-Shelf:

  • Affects: All frequencies above corner
  • Flat response: Above corner frequency
  • Transition: At corner frequency
  • Use: Brightness boost/cut, air control

Parameters:

  • Frequency: Corner/transition frequency
  • Gain: Amount of boost/cut (±dB)
  • Q/Slope: Steepness of transition (optional)

Low-Shelf Applications:

Add Warmth:

  • Frequency: 100-200Hz
  • Gain: +2 to +4dB
  • Use: Vocals, guitars, mix bus

Remove Mud:

  • Frequency: 200-300Hz
  • Gain: -2 to -4dB
  • Use: Guitars, overheads, busses

High-Shelf Applications:

Add Air/Brightness:

  • Frequency: 8-12kHz
  • Gain: +2 to +4dB
  • Use: Vocals, acoustic guitar, mix bus, mastering

Remove Harshness:

  • Frequency: 8-10kHz
  • Gain: -2 to -4dB
  • Use: Harsh sources, digital recordings, mastering

De-essing (Alternative):

  • Frequency: 6-8kHz
  • Gain: -3 to -6dB
  • Use: Sibilant vocals (instead of de-esser)

Q/Slope Control:

  • Low Q: Gentle, musical transition
  • High Q: Sharper, more focused
  • Typical: Q of 0.7-1.0 (moderate)

Shelving vs Bell:

  • Shelf: Affects all frequencies beyond point
  • Bell: Affects narrow band, returns to flat
  • Shelf: More transparent for broad adjustments
  • Bell: Better for specific frequency enhancement

---

intermediate.title: Identify: Gain/Amplitude (±dB)
intermediate.content: Which term best describes: "Amount of boost or cut applied at specific frequency."?
intermediate.explanation:
Gain/Amplitude (±dB)

Amount of boost or cut applied at specific frequency.

Measurement: Decibels (dB)

  • Positive (+dB): Boost (increases level)
  • Negative (-dB): Cut (decreases level)
  • 0dB: No change (unity gain)

Typical Boost/Cut Ranges:

  • Subtle: ±1-3dB (transparent, natural)
  • Moderate: ±3-6dB (noticeable, musical)
  • Aggressive: ±6-12dB (obvious, corrective)
  • Extreme: ±12dB+ (special effects, problem-solving)

Boosting:

  • Adds emphasis to frequencies
  • Can introduce phase shift
  • Reduces headroom (adds level)
  • Use: Enhancement, presence, character
  • Guideline: Boost 1-3dB typical, up to 6dB musical

Cutting:

  • Removes problematic frequencies
  • Less phase shift than boosting
  • Increases headroom (reduces level)
  • Use: Problem-solving, mud removal, harshness reduction
  • Guideline: Cut 3-6dB typical, up to 12dB+ for problems

Professional Philosophy:

  • "Cut to fix, boost to enhance": Cuts solve problems, boosts add character
  • "Make it worse, then better": Boost to find problem, cut to fix
  • "Wide cuts, narrow boosts": General guideline for musical EQ
  • "Less is more": Small moves (1-3dB) often sufficient

Perception:

  • 1dB: Barely noticeable, subtle
  • 3dB: Clearly noticeable
  • 6dB: Very noticeable, significant change
  • 10dB+: Extreme, obvious change

---

intermediate.title: Identify: High-Pass Filter (HPF) / Low-Cut Filter
intermediate.content: Which term best describes: "Removes frequencies below cutoff point, allows highs to pass."?
intermediate.explanation:
High-Pass Filter (HPF) / Low-Cut Filter

Removes frequencies below cutoff point, allows highs to pass.

Names:

  • High-Pass Filter (HPF): Describes what passes (highs)
  • Low-Cut Filter: Describes what's removed (lows)
  • Both terms: Mean same thing

Cutoff Frequency:

  • Point where signal is -3dB (half power)
  • Frequencies below: Progressively removed
  • Frequencies above: Pass through unaffected

Slope:

  • 6dB/octave (1-pole): Gentle, subtle removal
  • 12dB/octave (2-pole): Moderate, standard (most common)
  • 18dB/octave (3-pole): Steep, aggressive
  • 24dB/octave (4-pole): Very steep, brick-wall
  • Higher slopes: More aggressive removal, more phase shift

Applications:

Vocals:

  • Cutoff: 80-100Hz (removes rumble, plosives, room noise)
  • Slope: 12-18dB/octave
  • Benefit: Cleaner, clearer, more headroom

Guitars:

  • Cutoff: 80-120Hz (removes mud, rumble)
  • Slope: 12dB/octave
  • Benefit: Tighter, clearer low end

Snare Drum:

  • Cutoff: 80-100Hz (removes kick bleed, rumble)
  • Slope: 12-18dB/octave
  • Benefit: Cleaner snare, less mud

Overhead Cymbals:

  • Cutoff: 200-400Hz (removes cymbal wash, mud)
  • Slope: 12-18dB/octave
  • Benefit: Cleaner, brighter cymbals

Mix Bus:

  • Cutoff: 30-40Hz (removes sub-rumble, unnecessary lows)
  • Slope: 12dB/octave
  • Benefit: Tighter, cleaner low end, more headroom

"High-Pass Everything" Rule:

  • Except: Kick drum and bass
  • Removes: Unnecessary low-frequency content
  • Result: Cleaner mix, more headroom, less mud
  • Standard professional practice

Resonance/Q:

  • Some HPF have resonance control
  • Adds: Emphasis at cutoff frequency
  • Can add: Character or thinness
  • Usually: Keep at minimum (flat response)

---

intermediate.title: Identify: Center Frequency
intermediate.content: Which term best describes: "Exact frequency where EQ boost or cut is centered."?
intermediate.explanation:
Center Frequency

Exact frequency where EQ boost or cut is centered.

Selection:

  • Choose: Based on problem or enhancement goal
  • Sweep: To find resonances or sweetspots
  • Precise: In parametric EQ (20Hz-20kHz range)
  • Fixed: In graphic EQ (predetermined frequencies)

Finding Problem Frequencies: 1. Set large boost (+10dB) 2. Set narrow Q (3-5) 3. Sweep frequency range 4. Listen for harshness, resonance, or problems 5. When found, switch to cut with wider Q

Common Problem Frequencies:

  • 80-120Hz: Boominess in bass/kick
  • 200-400Hz: Muddiness, boxiness
  • 500Hz-1kHz: Honky, nasal quality
  • 2-4kHz: Harshness (electric guitars, vocals)
  • 6-8kHz: Sibilance (vocals)

Enhancement Frequencies:

  • 60-80Hz: Sub-bass weight
  • 100-200Hz: Warmth, body
  • 3-5kHz: Presence, clarity
  • 8-12kHz: Air, brilliance
  • 10-15kHz: Sparkle, sheen

---

intermediate.title: Identify: Low-Pass Filter (LPF) / High-Cut Filter
intermediate.content: Which term best describes: "Removes frequencies above cutoff point, allows lows to pass."?
intermediate.explanation:
Low-Pass Filter (LPF) / High-Cut Filter

Removes frequencies above cutoff point, allows lows to pass.

Names:

  • Low-Pass Filter (LPF): Describes what passes (lows)
  • High-Cut Filter: Describes what's removed (highs)
  • Both terms: Mean same thing

Cutoff Frequency:

  • Point where signal is -3dB
  • Frequencies above: Progressively removed
  • Frequencies below: Pass through unaffected

Slope:

  • Same as HPF: 6, 12, 18, 24 dB/octave
  • Steeper slope: More aggressive high-frequency removal

Applications:

Bass Guitar:

  • Cutoff: 5-8kHz (removes pick noise, string noise)
  • Slope: 6-12dB/octave
  • Benefit: Smoother, less harsh highs

Kick Drum:

  • Cutoff: 8-10kHz (removes beater click if too much)
  • Slope: 6-12dB/octave (gentle)
  • Benefit: Smooth, not clicky

Synthesizers:

  • Cutoff: Variable (subtractive synthesis)
  • Slope: 12-24dB/octave
  • Benefit: Tone shaping, warmth, character

De-harshing:

  • Cutoff: 12-16kHz (reduce brittle harshness)
  • Slope: 6dB/octave (gentle)
  • Benefit: Smoother, less fatiguing

"Tape" Effect:

  • Cutoff: 15-18kHz (simulate analog tape)
  • Slope: 6-12dB/octave
  • Benefit: Warmth, vintage character, "analog" sound

Less Common Than HPF:

  • Most instruments: Benefit from highs
  • HPF used more frequently
  • LPF: More specialized applications

---

intermediate.title: Identify: Bell Filter (Parametric Peak/Dip)
intermediate.content: Which term best describes: "Boost or cut centered at specific frequency with adjustable width (Q)."?
intermediate.explanation:
Bell Filter (Parametric Peak/Dip)

Boost or cut centered at specific frequency with adjustable width (Q).

Most Versatile EQ Type:

  • Full control: Frequency, gain, Q
  • Can boost or cut
  • Can be wide or narrow
  • Standard in parametric EQ

Parameters:

  • Frequency: Center of boost/cut
  • Gain: Amount of boost/cut (±dB)
  • Q: Width of affected band

Applications:

  • Most common EQ type
  • Surgical corrections (narrow Q)
  • Musical enhancements (wide Q)
  • Problem-solving
  • Creative shaping

Shape:

  • Bell curve (Gaussian)
  • Peak at center frequency
  • Tapers symmetrically on sides
  • Width determined by Q

---

[Content continues in Part 2 with EQ Types, Techniques, and Applications]
